Something went wrong with the Grav Drive. I've never seen the Planck mapping take that long, and it was stuck in a loop until I diverted all power to the drive.

I should've realized it was busted and just ran a diagnostic, but I decided to punch through.

So instead of jumping to Sol like we planned, we landed in the middle of an asteroid field. I managed to steer us out of it, but we took some heavy damage. 

Damn. This is on me.I had Iris do a post-mortem and analyze the grav drive system. According to her, the inferometer calibration is broken. None of the mappings are anywhere near the destination.

And that's the just for starters. Aleksy and Pete have been combing over the rest of the ship, and the news is grim. The collision with the asteroid caused a stress fracture to multiple exhaust pipes. A scan of the air quality shows high levels of ammonia and hydrogen chloride.

Some of the tools we'll need to do repairs have also been damaged, meaning our best option is to seal off the toxic areas and try to signal for help.
Haven't seen another ship pass by for days. Now we've got corrosive liquid flooding the ship on top of the gas leaks, and the cockpit is off limits. So we'll have to cross our fingers and pray someone docks with the ship.

The ship is done, no repair job can fix it now. And since a rescue's our only hope, we're going to seal ourselves in the crew quarters and wait it out.

Can you believe it, honey?! I'm coming home!

I can't wait to hold our son. I bet he looks just like me! Hopefully, he won't be a hot head like his father and go get himself injured in some war haha.

I love you and can't wait to see you.

[REDACTED] started complaining of irregular sleep patterns, disconcerting dreams, and eventually, insomnia. Offers of leave were made, but refused by [REDACTED]. 

(NOTE: This was the first error. Employee sleep patterns will need to be more closely monitored going forward and regular leave required, not offered.)

On the night of the incident, [REDACTED] asked their direct supervisor if he could take a sample from specimen M4. Authorization was granted and [REDACTED] proceeded to M4's cage.

(NOTE: Second error. Access to cages need to be multi-step authorization, not something a lone supervisor can decide.)

Upon reaching M4's cage, however, rather than properly subduing the specimen, [REDACTED] simply unlocked the cage, allowing M4 to exit. M4 walked past [REDACTED] without harming him, but, upon further progress, the biological alarm systems engaged as expected and M4 was immediately disposed of by the Marine contingent on duty. No casualties occurred (and we got very lucky).

[REDACTED] was found unconscious outside the cage door, checked for injury, and placed under arrest. 

___________________________
Result
>> [REDACTED] has been returned to New Atlantis and is currently awaiting trial for reckless endangerment.
>>> His name has been expunged from the record pending trial results.
___________________________

Notation: Terrormorph influence is an explicit, short-term affliction, not something that could allow for a multi-step plan like this. And everyone in this facility is tested for susceptibility to Terrormorph attacks. You don't get in the door if you might turn. Which means that either:

A. Due to stress and lack of sleep, [REDACTED] simply made an error when trying to collect a sample.

B. Terrormorphs are capable of far more insidious and complex influence than anyone thought possible.

Occum's Razor - the simplest explanation is usually the correct one - says it has to be the lack of sleep... but the Terrormorph didn't maul him when it got out. There wasn't a scratch on the man. Terrormorphs usually only save that kind of reverence for each other and those creatures under their sway. Regardless of explicit mental domination or not, some sort of a relationship was formed here. We'll be doing some additional investigation to see if we can't figure out what that was.

Regardless, we're putting in the above-noted safety measures so nothing like this happens again.

Beginning in 2196, the Narion War - humanity's first large-scale conflict among the stars - is remembered as a defining moment for the Settled Systems. 

As the first major conflict to make extensive use of grav jump-enabled ships, the Narion War was less defined by key space battles and more by an extended, cat-and-mouse interplay between the two powers, as the well-armed and professional UC Navy tried again and again to pin down the piecemeal but savvy Freestar fleet.

Unable to strike the killing blow, the UC resorted to ever more severe tactics to try and drive the Collective to capitulate, but without success. In fact, after many long years of war with little to show for it, even the populace of the UC itself began to turn against the cause, with protests roiling even New Atlantis, the citizenry demanding the war finally come to a humane close. So, when at long last, the final blow was struck - with the UC Navy finally cornering and obliterating the Freestar fleet in 2216 -  it was a hollow victory. 

It was from the resulting negotiations - The Treaty of Narion - that the Settled Systems as we know them today emerged, both literally and figuratively. 

Despite winning the war, the UC found themselves in an unenviable position, painted as a brutal aggressor even in their home systems. So, in the spirit of unity and lasting peace, the UC agreed to the demands of the Freestar Collective and the Narion settlers whose collusion triggered the conflict in the first place, and handed over Narion to the Collective, as they had requested at the start of hostilities (including the Clinic medical starstation), creating the Freestar Collective as we know it to this day.

In return, the UC demanded two concessions: the first was payment for damages done in the form of mineral rights on multiple worlds across the galaxy. 

The second, more significant demand was that no great faction may ever colonize more than three systems. The UC would have Alpha Centauri, Sol, and Wolf, and the Freestar Collective, Cheyenne, Volii, and Narion. 

The Freestar Collective agreed to these terms, creating - and codifying into law - the Settled Systems as we know them today. The Treaty of Narion has since become the foundation of all contemporary political relations, and it's only official violation, the cause of the galaxy's greatest conflict - the Colony War.

To learn more about the Colony War, please proceed to the "Conflict Among the Stars" mural.

This public terminal is available for your use! 

All entries made here will be visible to other travelers who come through the colony. If you have extra goods to sell or warnings to offer other merchants, please feel free to enter them here. 

Several colonies throughout the Settled Systems are participating in this program. Our goal is to make the spacelanes a safer for traveling merchants, and give you all a way to stay in touch. Please spread the word at any new colonies you encounter! 

Good luck out there!

Your friends at the colony of Bluebonnet 

Hello, fellow travelers!

My name's Oren. I'm a long-hauler for Dogstar. My ship's always stocked with extra components for travelers in need. I sell in the spacelanes, and I also work with vendors at Nekoville, Bluebonnet, and Lucky Day. Mention this terminal entry for a discount. 

Keep an eye out for my ship, "Merryweather", if you're traveling in the area. I'm always looking for new customers.

Oren Looking for a change of scenery? Consolidated Mining is always hiring! 

Miners earn a generous base wage, with bonuses available based on performance and the value of any resources mined at their site. 

Inquire about your next big opportunity with one of our traveling recruiters, or hop a ship to any major Settlement and find us there. We can't wait to meet you! 

Luna,

This is Carlie Banner, the traveling nurse you met in Cydonia. You left your sketchbook at the bar! I'm sure you want it back, everything in there is gorgeous. I'm holding onto it for now so nothing happens to it. 

It sounds like we usually travel the same routes, so I'm leaving messages for you wherever I can! My next stop is Lucky Day, then I'm headed to New Homestead to resupply. Hope to meet up soon. I'll keep your gorgeous portraits safe and sound in the meantime.

Cheers,

CarlieATTENTION ALL TRAVELERS!!

I've seen a big jump in the number of Va'ruun Zealot ships around Bluebonntet lately! If you see them, GET AWAY! You won't beat them in a fight, and they don't want to trade with us. For everybody's sake, don't tick them off!

PLEASE STAY SAFE!!!!!!

Junyi Chin, Bluebonnet resident

When it comes to the Well, there's no other word for it but Dickensian. How the United Colonies continues to let this space fester and grow is beyond my comprehension. Do they not understand that its existence is like an infection that becomes gangrenous with time?

The entire area is full of vandals, extortionists, and petty thieves. As far as I'm concerned, UC Security needs to take a hard, zero tolerance policy and start arresting them all en masse.
The other day some Well rat picked my pocket. It was just as I was leaving the NAT. He had his head down and bumped into me as he was making his way down the ramp, It wasn't until I reached my desk that I realized what happened. To think, I actually apologized to the thief!

I reported the crime immediately to Sergeant Yumi, but he seemed reluctant to bring UC Security down into the Well. Apparently my description was too vague. I suggested he simply arrested them all as a joke, but he didn't find it particularly funny.Since Sergeant Yumi doesn't have the resources to investigate the crimes in the Well, I've taken it upon myself to visit Aegis and see if I can't find a record of the miscreant in the civilian database.

It took longer than was comfortable, but I think I found a match. A young man, employed as a cargo hauler, and previously served time for vandalism, but escaped jail time due to a medical condition. Tahir Vala.

Got the situation under control, Captain! Turns out there was a slight misalignment in engine bay 6 causing all that rumbling. We were able to scrounge up some scrap metal and secure it. Luckily, Zuska was small enough to climb in there to weld it in place, else we would have had to rip up the lavatories to get at it, and I know that wouldn't have sat well with anyone on board. But anyway. Job's done and hey, no more shaking!

-Amin> I'm out of ideas. 
> The first few ships we saw when we arrived were quick to divert away from us. The one 
> that stopped and seemed to want to communicate with us left after attempts failed. 
> Yue  said the signal came through all garbled. It could be whatever language the 
> creatures speak, or it could be an incompatibility with our comm systems. Yue isn't 
> sure. Amin has no idea. If we still had the landing craft, we could just ventured down
> ourselves. We even tried something called "morse code" that Julia suggested out of 
> an old book. It's basically a message conveyed by flashing our lights on and off at 
> various intervals, but either they aren't able to decode it, or worse, no one's even 
> looking. I could use your counsel.
>
> -Captain Diana Brackenridge

I believe our best course of action is to remain here and keep waiting. Whoever or whatever they are, they're bound to attempt a docking procedure with us at some point. They may be equally worried. I recommend preparing a select welcoming party. When it occurs, we should be careful, but welcoming. You've done a wonderful job briefing the crew and maintaining order. Keep at it. We will get through this.

-Mabhuti> Beloved crew of the ECS Constant,
> First, the excellent news. We have arrived at New Jamestown! The mission our forebears 
> initiated hundreds of years ago is a resounding success!
> 
> However, with no landing craft, we remain stuck in orbit. The plan was always to 
> dismantle parts of the Constant once we arrived in orbit, and attempt to construct a 
> new landing craft. However, we have also learned that the planet appears inhabited. 
> Before we jump to conclusions, we cannot say with certainty this is alien life. So far, 
> efforts to communicate have not succeeded. Our goal is now to attempt to meet with 
> them and arrange transport, rather than risk undue damage to our current home. 
> Then, we can negotiate our rights to the planet. Thank you for remaining calm in these

>
> -Captain Diana Brackenridge

Hello!

Welcome to the city of New Atlantis, capital of the United Colonies, and for many, the Settled Systems as a whole. You stand now in the most technologically advanced city the human race has ever conceived and constructed. 

New Atlantis was founded in the year 2160, a mere four years after we first arrived in the Alpha Centauri star system. If you're a resident, then you're already familiar with your fantastic home! And if you're a visitor, you are an honored guest of the United Colonies, and will be treated as such. 

Our courteous and professional Security personnel can be found all over the city, and it's their job to ensure your time in New Atlantis is joyful, lawful, and productive.

So as you stroll the streets, or take the NAT train to the city's different districts, know that you are in the embrace of the United Colonies, and couldn't be in better hands.We are the children of Earth.

The United Colonies as an entity was first established in the year 2159, on the planet Earth, as a means of unifying the human race as we spread amongst the stars. Our goal was the peaceful exploration and colonization of space, working in harmony with anyone who wished to sail forth across the blackest sea, to new horizons. In 2161, we issued the Centaurus Proclamation, which formalized the colonization of distant worlds for anyone who wished to do so.

Unfortunately, not everyone shared in our dream. When wars erupted across the Settled Systems, the United Colonies stood steadfast, protecting humans and their right to fairly colonize.

And then, when our beloved home world was rendered uninhabitable in the year 2203, the United Colonies knew it had a sacred responsibility - we were to be the keepers of Earth. Its artifacts. Its ideals. Its cultures. Its very people.

So while you stand now on the planet Jemison, in the city of New Atlantis, in the Alpha Centauri star system, know that for all intents and purposes, you are still very much on Earth. 

And Earth takes care of its own.


Here in New Atlantis, a citizen or visitor can find just about any service they may need. From freshly brewed coffee to complete body reconstruction, we have it all!

The following is a list of corporations and businesses that have found a home in New Atlantis. (District location is indicated in parentheses.)

- TerraBrew Coffee (Spaceport, Commercial)
- Jemison Mercantile (Spaceport)
- The Viewport Tavern (Spaceport)
- Centurion Arsenal (Residential)
- Reliant Medical - (Residential)
- Enhance! (Commercial)
- Chunks (Residential)
- CJ's (Residential)
- EIT Clothier (Residential) 
- Outland (Commercial)
- Jake's (The Well)
- Apex Electronics (The Well)
Here in New Atlantis, you'll find a wide variety of buildings that provide various functions and services. They include:

·	GalBank (Commercial)
·	SSNN (Commercial) 
·	The Trade Authority (The Well)
·	Sanctum Universum Church (MAST)
·	House of Enlightenment (The Well)
·	Freestar Collective Embassy (MAST)
·	House Va'ruun Embassy (MAST)
·	Infinity LTD Corporate Headquarters (Commercial)
·	MedBay (The Well)
·	UC Surplus (The Well)

It's impossible to visit New Atlantis and not notice the imposing structure that is MAST. Much more than a building, MAST also serves as the very foundation of the United Colonies. There, the Military, Administrative and Scientific Triumverate works tirelessly to ensure continuing peace and prosperity for everyone under the UC's protection.

The foundation of any society is its people, and there is no stronger person than a United Colonies citizen. As a citizen, you will carry a status unequaled in the Settled Systems, and will be recognized as the truly special individual you are. Whether you make your home in New Atlantis, Cydonia, or any other officially recognized settlement, citizenship is the truest badge of loyalty and dedication to the United Colonies you can possess.
As a United Colonies citizen, you will be afforded the following privileges:

* An exclusive and personalized acknowledgement of your new status
* A welcome letter signed by none other than President Alexandra Abello herself 
* Discounts at all major United Colonies business establishments
* Exclusive access to home ownership in New Atlantis
* A one-time credit disbursement
* And more!

How does one become a citizen? It's easy! Simply serve the United Colonies in any official capacity, and once you've met the allotted requirements, citizenship will be granted. 
 
Currently, the fastest and simplest way to achieve citizenship is to complete a tour of duty in the Vanguard, the United Colonies' very own volunteer fleet. So if you've got your own ship, and the moxie to put yourself in harm's way for the good of the UC, speak with Commander John Tuala in MAST and get signed up today!
 
Note that as of this time, the United Colonies offers citizenship to anyone within the Settled Systems, regardless of current address or faction affiliation. If you want the United Colonies, the United Colonies wants you!

I was at the tram station minding my own business when I saw the vandal, Tahir Vala, try to spray paint one of the signs. I immediately recognized Mr. Vala from a prior incident, and called for security. Perhaps that was my mistake.

Alerted by my call, he quickly darted toward the tram, and the doors closed before I could catch him.

Regardless, he can't hide from UC Security any longer. I'll be putting a call to Sergeant Yumi immediately to have a squad dispatched to Kay's House in the Well. I'll also provide a full statement as soon as I have a moment.Suspect: Tahir Vala
Occupation: Cargo Hauler
Hair: Black
Eyes: Brown
Weight: 80 kg (Approximation)
Height: 1.8 meters
Location: Residence unknown, but often spends time at Kay's in the Well

I could pass this information to Sergeant Yumi, but given his previous reluctance, I'm not sure anything would come of it. However, I will keep this information on file in the event other reports of criminal activity come in. Recidivism in the Well is high, and it's only a matter of time before Mr. Vala strikes again. When it happens, I'll be the first to contact UC Security and let them know who's at fault.

I've lost two recon teams and one rescue team. None of them made it. We can't even risk trying to retrieve the bodies.

I'm sealing off this site per Ultraviolet Protocols. You need to get a courier to the client IMMEDIATELY. There's no way this is a coincidence.

But requiring only Omega Class personnel effectively means our sworn-to-secrecy grunts are doing all the manual work, instead of subcontracted techs. May 6th, 2330

Sent around the usual message to the others about recruiting. I hate to nag, but I don't know what else to do. We're way below where I'd like us to be, and if there really is another smuggling syndicate setting up shop in the Freestar Collective, we're going to be spread dangerously thin.

At this point, I'm ready to accept any halfway decent candidate who walks into the Rock. Emma's got an eye for talent, and I trust her to weed out anyone that's unfit. If it gets the Council off my back, I ain't going to complain.
May 3rd, 2330

I'm starting to worry about Autumn. As much as I'd like to deny it, Emma might be right. Maybe tracking down that new smuggling syndicate we've been getting reports about was too big an assignment. She's young, headstrong and ain't the best at keeping in touch while she's out in the field, so the long silence might mean she's in some kind of trouble.

For now, I'm going to sit tight and hope we get some kind of word soon. Emma always says we've got to have faith in the people we give a badge to, so for now I'll stay the course. But if another week goes by without news, I might need to send someone out to track her down.

I ain't much for superstition or luck, but I'll cross my fingers anyway.May 1st, 2330

Seems like every time I get a slate from one of the Governors, they've just got to bring up retirement. "We ain't trying to push you into it," they all say, "we're just looking to the future. Got to be prepared, after all!" 

Feels like I've read some version of that a half dozen times in the past month alone. 

I've got no illusions that I'm the best Marshal the Rangers ever had, but damn, am I doing such a bad job that they want me gone? Or is it something else? No way I'd believe Emma would go around behind my back and talk to the Council. She jokes about it, sure, but I trust her like family.

What would I even do, anyway? Am I supposed to set up some farm on my own and while away my last days watching the crops grow until the sun goes down? To hell with that. Truth is, I live for the job and nothing else. When I can't do that anymore, I'll hang up my spurs. The Governors can wait.

Ansalaga, Marina

This public terminal is available for your use! 

All entries made here will be visible to other travelers who come through the colony. If you have extra goods to sell or warnings to offer other merchants, please feel free to enter them here. 

Several colonies throughout the Settled Systems are participating in this program. Our goal is to make the spacelanes a safer for traveling merchants, and give you all a way to stay in touch. Please spread the word at any new colonies you encounter! 

Good luck out there!

Your friends at the colony of Nekoville 

Just seeing who's out there! Add your name, your ship's name, and a brief description of what you do to the list, so we can get to know each other. See you all in the spacelanes! 

Perry Trace - Sailor's Delight - Traveling engineer who services independent colonies

Ludi Yang - Sweet Dream IV - Traveling saleswoman for Boom Pop! Try our new flavors today! 

Nadia Hertzeg - Moonflower - Adventurer at large. Find me among the stars! 

Luna Wright - Latitude - Official resort painter for Paradiso

Jio Osaka - Mother's Tongue - Traveling vendor specializing in organic goods

Andromeda Kepler - Leonardo da Vinci - Writer, philosopher, admirer of the universe. Be well.

Rakhil Sohman -  Earth's Bounty - Recruiter for Consolidated Mining. Join up today! 

Elliot Vane - Martian Moon - Geological Surveyor for Six Sisters Mining. Hello, galaxy! 

Omar Nevin - Gravitas - Traveling food and wine vendor. Good to see you on this list, Jio! Hi all,

My name's Perry Trace. I'm a former MAST engineer who got sick of life in the big city and struck out on my own. I make an annual circuit between all the minor colonies in the nearby systems repairing robots and doing general engineering work. 

Lately, I've noticed a lot of travelers in outdated ships that need repairs. It seems like high-end fixes are beyond most people's means, and it's putting a lot of you at risk. So starting now, I'm offering to fix your ship for FREE! Any traveler in need can find me along my route and get any repairs done at no cost. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you're in need! 

Best of luck, and safe travels

Dr. Perry Omar Nevin here, with the best news you've heard all day! Chandra Vineyards overstocked my hull, so I have wine to sell for cheap. Classy stuff, too. Good enough for Trident Luxury. 

I'll keep my overstock set aside for travelers like us. We work hard, we all deserve to kick back and relax with a glass of merlot. Hit me up at any of the colonies with terminals like these, or find me in Akila City and let's make a trade. My ship's called "Gravitas". Give me a ring if you see me in the spacelanes. I'm always down to share a bottle with a fellow traveler. 

Cheers! 

OmarHi everyone,

My name's Nadia, and I'd like to buy your old magazines! I'm looking for legacy editions of The New Atlantian that feature "Mickey Caviar's Taste of Space!". I'll take editorial columns, restaurant reviews, or recipes. They can be in any condition, as long as the text is readable.  

I'll accept credits or trades. My hull's always full, so name your price! You'll find me traveling between Bluebonnet, Nekoville, and Lucky Day.

Safe travels, and stay spicy!

Nadia

Your friends at the colony of Lucky Day 

Hey, travelers,

My name's Luna. I paint landscapes for Paradiso resorts. I'm in kind of a pickle, hopefully someone here can help me out. 

I lost my sketchbook! It disappeared somewhere between Cydonia and here. I've turned my ship upside down and haven't found it anywhere. If you come across it, please hold onto it and leave me a message on one of these terminals! If I get it back in one piece, I'll paint you something as a thank you. 

Safe travels!

Luna Wright  Hey galaxy, the name's Decland Rhoads. I'm about to set off on a solo journey into uncharted space. The Settled Systems has gotten a little small for my taste. It's time we see what else is out there.  

I'm leaving this message as a record of my location, in case I don't make it back. My parents' names are Jess and Michael Rhoads. They live in New Atlantis, in Athena Tower. 

My plan is to be back two years from the date of this message. If and when I return, I'll delete this message. Should the worst happen, I'd be obliged if someone could let my parents know that this is the last place I was seen. Fingers crossed that it won't come to that. 

Make your way,

DeclandTip for all travelers in the area. If you're hailed by a friendly ship captained by an old woman, do yourself a favor and stop for her! She invited me for dinner, and we had a wonderful conversation. Plus, she makes some of the best food this side of the Brown Horse Tavern. By the end of the evening, she was packing my ship full of leftovers and asking me to call her "Granny". It was just what I needed after months in the spacelanes. Keep your eyes peeled for her! Hello traveling merchants,

The name's Jio Osaka. I'm a merchant who specializes in organic goods. I've been having trouble running my route lately thanks to the growing number of spacers in this area. To combat this, I've founded a merchant group. Safety in numbers, right? 

A few other vendors who travel this part of the spacelanes are already on board. Omar Nevin, Aura Shelby, and Julie Fearth (you probably know her as Jumping Jules) have committed to traveling together. All are great pilots, and fantastic company. Come and join us! 

See you soon,

Jio

Dear students,

We've reached the halfway point in our expedition, and as such I'll be requiring each of you to complete a lengthy midterm assignment to showcase what you've learned. You'll need to make time for this in addition to your regular duties around the outpost. I know that's asking a lot, but you're all capable of it. 

It is imperative that you read ALL the instructions for parts one through four before you begin. Failure to do so may put you in a bad spot, as there a handful of specific requirements. I'm sure you're all well aware of the importance of properly following instructions by now. 

I look forward to seeing your submissions! 

Prof. Eiserloh The first portion of this assignment will evaluate your ability to properly catalog a specimen. Please read ALL instructions carefully before you begin. 

Step 1. Locate a specimen with which you are unfamiliar. This specimen MUST represent a different scientific discipline than the one you major in. Zoology students may not use organic specimens, geology students may not use mineral samples, etc. 

Step 2. Write a 500 word description of your specimen. The description must be handwritten. Please include at least five footnotes, and a nicely-written title. If I cannot read your handwriting, you will fail this portion of the assignment! 

Step 3. Prepare your sample for a museum-style viewing. You may use any materials found around the outpost to construct your display, but it must be professional quality! Your display should include a pedestal for your sample, and a copy of your specimen description for viewers to read. You may not use the original description from step 2. I will be evaluating that one separately. 

Step 4. Write a two-minute presentation about your chosen sample. Presentations must be memorized by the assignment due date. The second portion of this assignment will be a specimen sketch. Please read ALL instructions carefully before you begin: 

Step 1. Locate a suitable specimen for sketching. Your subject may be biological or inorganic. I will evaluate all sketches based on quality of artistic expression, not subject matter.

Step 2. Complete a set of basic specimen sketches with labels and relevant notes. Capture your specimen from three separate angles on the same page. Each sketch must capture the essence of your chosen specimen in a creative and interesting way. Label your sketches "A", "B," and "C."

Step 3. Swap sketches with your regular research partner. Now, carefully color in their sketches. Sketch A should be shaded in graphite, sketch B painted in watercolor, and sketch C colored with charcoal. 

Step 4. Collect your partner's renderings of your sketches, and add them to the museum display you constructed for part one of this assignment. 

Step 5. Work with your partner to write a brief, collaborative artist's statement about the sketches you created together. They should be displayed alongside your sketches. The third portion of this assignment will focus on putting the field skills you've learned on this expedition to the test. Please read ALL instructions before you begin. 

Step 1. Consult a topographical map of the region surrounding our research station. Work with a partner (not your regular research partner) to identify a location more than half a kilometer from here which you feel might be interesting based on topographical data alone. If you need to borrow a map, I'd be happy to loan you one. 

Step 2. Trek to your chosen location with your partner. Leave at sunset. Bring along a telescope, a map, and any materials you need for identifying creatures. You'll be spending the night there, so dress warm! 

Step 3. Spend 8 to 12 hours at your chosen location, carefully observing and documenting all biological, geological, AND astronomical activity you observe. You and your partner may work collaboratively to take notes. I expect at least 10 pages of detailed observation. 

Step 4. After you return to the research station, prepare a detailed report using your notes. Your report must include at least three first-person andecdotes, and a description of one particularly interesting astronomical event you observed. 

Step 5. Working with your partner, create a SECOND museum-style display for your report. All papers should be nicely mounted to a corkboard or the research station's wall. I'll be checking your work!Part four of this assignment will evaluate your ability to follow basic instructions.

Step 1. Disregard parts one through three of this assignment entirely. Instead, prepare a five minute presentation on the most interesting thing you've learned on this expedition so far. When you're finished, come to me and we'll discuss over tea.

Step 2. Find your reward! I've hidden a few bottles of nice wine, some good books, and a handful of other goodies somewhere in the outpost. They're yours if you can find them. Enjoy a glass of wine while your peers are trekking across the planet's surface questioning their decision to take my class. 

Congratulations to those of you who read the instructions first. You've saved yourself days of work, and proven that you're capable of following directions from a lead researcher. You have what it takes to work in the field.

Gotcha,

Eiserloh

Hi Trent,

This is Ayesha, your Arc Might liason for this star system. We met last week during Ryujin's Worker Welfare Inspection. I'm delighted to say that you passed with flying colors! 55 days with no injuries is extremely impressive, given the tight deadline on your project and the long hours your workers have been putting in.

Your team's stellar performance has earned you one of Arc Might's merit-based Onsite Bonus Packages! We've filled it with a suite of items that we think will make your team's experience even better. 

Congrats again! We don't get to give these out to foremen very often.

AyeshaHi Ayesha,

I'm glad to hear that you were happy with what you saw at my site. The crew has been working hard to keep that no-injury streak going. It hasn't been easy, like you said.

Thanks for sending us the bonus package. Everyone was grateful for the gifts. But they've been asking about raising wages, too. Our team was told that an injury-free run of 50 days or longer would get us a 20% increase in our pay. Is that something I can tell them to expect soon?

Thank you,

TrentHi Trent,

Unfortunately, Arc Might's policies have changed in the two weeks since your team's Worker Welfare Inspection. We are no longer providing that type of bonus to high-performing teams. We hope that your Onsite Bonus Package makes a suitable substitute. I'd appreciate if you let your team know about the policy update. 

Keep up the great work!

Ayesha

This research team's goal is to evaluate the potential for large-scale human habitation on a variety of planets throughout the Settled Systems. Our intention is to support the future expansion of the United Colonies by locating suitable planets upon which new cities and settlements might be built. 

Our team is comprised of experts in a variety of scientific disciplines. Each of us will seperately evaluate the planets we visit based on a wide range of criteria, then work together as a team to develop a report on the overall suitability of the planet for human habitation. 

At MAST's direction, we will evaluate three planets total before returning to New Atlantis. If the data collected on this expedition proves valuable, we intend to survey a dozen or so more. 


PROPERTY OF THE UNITED COLONIES. DATA NOT INTENDED FOR PUBLIC DISTRIBUTION.Contributing Researchers: Dr. Juli Aigner, Dr. William Clarke, Kallyn Thibodeau

After conducting three weeks of intensive research on this planet's surface, our team has concluded that this location is NOT suitable for long-term human habitation. We have made this determination based on a number of factors including soil composition and the presence of a predatory fungus that infects all flora present here.

While we do not believe this planet would be well-suited for civilian life, our team suggests the development of a research outpost here. We have found significant evidence of new species on this planet that warrant study by MAST's Scientific Division. 

Our team's individual findings are documented here for posterity.

PROPERTY OF THE UNITED COLONIES. DATA NOT INTENDED FOR PUBLIC DISTRIBUTION.Contributing Researcher: Dr. Juli Aigner

All I can say is - wow! In my first week here, I discovered what I believe to be a new species of fungus growing among the roots of most of the area's native plants. I've bagged several samples for analysis when I return to MAST. 

Unfortunately, this fungus is parasitic in nature. Every attempt I made to cultivate seedlings in the planet's topsoil was a failure. Fungus rotted away their roots within 48 to 72 hours of planting. Whatever adaptation keeps the local flora from being destroyed by this fungus is absent in their extraterrestrial cousins. 

I suggest that MAST sends a dedicated team of botanists to continue studying this area. I'd be more than willing to lead the team myself, once my current expedition is finished. Contributing Researcher: Kallyn Thibodeau

This planet isn't much to write home about, zoologically-speaking. The population of creatures is too sparse to make them useful as a food source, nor did they yield any particularly interesting data. Analysis of biological samples collected from several individuals of various species suggests no significant genetic difference between these creatures and the ones I've studied throughout my dissertation. 

At Dr. Juli's direction, I documented the behavior of nearby herbivores to determine whether they suffered any ill effects from eating plants that host the fungus she discovered here. My observation yielded nothing of particular interest. The herbivores that call this planet home don't appear to be picky eaters. 
Contributing Researcher: Dr. William Clarke

Very little to say about this planet on the geological front. No evidence of significant seismic activity or other geological turmoil in the planet's past. There are inorganic resources here in moderate quantities, but I've detected no trace of anything particularly valuable. 

The planet's topsoil is highly acidic, and drains extremely quickly. Even if Dr. Juli's newly-discovered fungus were eradicated, I doubt crops would thrive here. Dr. Juli's expert analysis suggests the same.

It would seem I drew the short straw on this stop. Better luck next time.

Our intention is to support the future expansion of the United Colonies by locating suitable planets upon which new cities and settlements might be built.

At MAST's direction, we will evaluate three planets total before returning to New Atlantis. If the data collected on this expedition proves valuable, we intend to survey a dozen or so more. 


PROPERTY OF THE UNITED COLONIES. DATA NOT INTENDED FOR PUBLIC DISTRIBUTION.Contributing Researchers: Dr. Juli Aigner, Dr. William Clarke, Kallyn Thibodeau

After conducting three weeks of intensive research on this planet's surface, our team has concluded that this location IS suitable for long-term human habitation. This planet boasts an abundance of peaceful creatures that would be suitable for use as a food source, and mineral-rich topsoil perfect for growing crops. 

Our team spent considerable time trekking around the area near our landing site in order to locate suitable places for future settlements. We've left behind several markers for future teams. Each warrants further investigation by the UC as a potential building site. 



PROPERTY OF THE UNITED COLONIES. DATA NOT INTENDED FOR PUBLIC DISTRIBUTION.Contributing Researcher: Dr. Juli Aigner

This planet may very well be a farmer's paradise. I planted my usual suite of seedlings, and found that they tripled in size around 20% more quickly than seedlings planted on Jemison. I'm no meteorologist, but I suspect this planet's atmosphere must be rich in carbon dioxide to facilitate such a high growth rate. 

I removed a sizeable chunk of soil from our landing site, and introduced my newly-discovered fungus to it in a controlled environment, along with a handful of seedlings. My initial hypothesis that the fungus would spread unchecked was disproven. It withered into a collection of dust-like spores within hours, leaving healthy seedlings behind. I now find myself the proprieter of a small shipboard garden. A truly delightful externality, and one my colleagues have reveled in. I'll make a botanist of Kallyn someday.  Contributing Researcher: Kallyn Thibodeau

I've observed remarkable biodiversity on this planet. There are large populations of herbivores, which appear sustainable enough to be used as a food source in a limited capacity. The predatory creatures that live here demonstrate no interest in attacking humans unless provoked. 

I've grown quite fond of a species of small insect-like creatures that live here. They're extremely curious, and have no innate fear of humans. Whenever I sit down to observe the local creatures' behaviors, one or two of them will inevitably crowd around me to investigate my gear. I wish I could take one home, but detailed sketches will have to do. I'll find an excuse to return here someday and continue my observations. I don't think Dr. William or Dr. Juli would be opposed to joining me. 
Contributing Researcher: Dr. William Clarke

This has been a truly remarkable stop. My colleagues determined early on that this planet would be suitable for habitation. I've dedicated the majority of my time here to assessing the nearby landscape to determine the best place for future settlements.

Based on the topography of the nearby landscape, some terraforming will be required if the UC decides to establish a settlement here. However, my analysis of the bedrock suggests that it will play nice with demolition equipment. Construction teams should have no significant issues leveling large sections of terrain for building.

After conducting three weeks of intensive research on this planet's surface, our team has concluded that this location MAY BE suitable for habitation. The conditions are similar to Titan's, and any settlements established here should be modeled after New Homestead. 

Our team feels that an appropriate next step would be sending a properly-equipped research team here long-term to study the climate's effects on growing times for crops and the seasonal behavior of the local creatures. Unfortunately, our team is not fully equipped to establish a remote greenhouse, and we lack the proper gear for long treks in these rough conditions. 


PROPERTY OF THE UNITED COLONIES. DATA NOT INTENDED FOR PUBLIC DISTRIBUTION.Contributing Researcher: Dr. Juli Aigner

Nothing of note to contribute here. This planet is an icecube, with insufficent soil for growing anything. I doubt even mentha spicata, that most pernicious of herbs, would thrive here. 

If I were properly equipped, I could establish a greenhouse to evaluate how my usual suite of seedlings performed in artificial conditions. Unfortunately, that endeavor will need to be undertaken by a different (and better funded) expedition.

In better news, my shipboard garden is thriving. We had fresh produce with dinner last night. Such a delight after months of packaged food. Contributing Researcher: Kallyn Thibodeau

This planet's conditions have led to some fascinating adaptations on the part of its fauna. At least, I think they have. It's been difficult to observe them up close, since the weather's been so rough. 

I've spent most of my time here polishing research notes and adding detail to my specimen sketches in preparation for a post-expedition presentation to my advisors. Dr. William's been a big help there. Sounds like he went to art school in another life. Who knew? 
Contributing Researcher: Dr. William Clarke

Based on the topography of the nearby landscape, some terraforming will be required if the UC decides to establish a settlement here. However, my analysis of the bedrock suggests that it will play nice with demolition equipment. Construction teams should have no significant issues leveling large sections of terrain for building.

Displayed here are works created by Va'ruun artisans, personally selected by our magnanimous leader Anasko Va'ruun to exhibit one of the many facets of Va'ruun culture. It is his sincere hope that through the shared appreciation of art, our societies may better relate in these portentous times.The "Coil" series of sculptures by renowned artist Deran Ma'leen are an attempt to explore the spirit of the Great Serpent. While His Visage is unknowable to all but Jinan Va'ruun, the only man to have beheld His Grandeur, we may still endeavor to imagine that moment.While the snakes of Old Earth can in no way be compared to the immeasurable power of the Great Serpent, they serve as a starting point for many aspiring artists in Dazra. This traditional piece was created by a second year student who has gone on to be a proud contributor to the legacy of House Va'ruun.Here Deran Ma'leen calls to mind the majesty of the Scaled Citadel, the home of our great leader Anasko Va'ruun, as well as the resting place of our founder, Jinan Va'ruun. The High Council of House Va'ruun has guided us since it's creation from high within this mighty structure.The Mourning, the flagship of House Va'ruun, and the first vessel used to make contact with the Settled Systems, was decommissioned in 2299. This piece of its hull is a symbol of the great works House Va'ruun has achieved in its time.

Note: Returned to Dazra by direct order of Anasko Va'ruun.

Lan Hsu: I never actually got to visit your labs back when we were working on the Grav Drive projects.

Victor Aiza: Seems like ancient history now. Only thing we're doing these days is launching weather satellites.

Lan Hsu: Guess this is as good a retirement as any. Now Project Demeter. You want our help manufacturing scanners to better track these new meteorological patterns we're seeing?

Judith Tatienne: Our guess is that the poles might be naturally shifting, causing some gravitational fluctuations that are throwing off our old models.

Lan Hsu: Why do you need the scanning tolerances to be so small? What are you trying to find?

Victor Aiza: I... just want to be sure. It's not like we're doing much these days, anyway. The glory days are over. Why not give ourselves a challenge before they write us off in the history books?To: Judith Tatienne, Victor Aiza, Lan Hsu

As requested, the Astrophysics Research Team has done a full analysis of the data you provided us. The measurements of the Earth's magnetosphere show clear signs of fluctuation, often in correlation to the periods of frequent and large gravity wave spikes emanating from the Moon.

These gravity waves seem to be affecting the magnetic shield provided by the Earth's inner core and may be affecting the core itself give the proximity to the source. The data indicates the change rate is increasing exponentially.

As our magnetosphere falters, its ability to protect us from the Sun's solar wind falters. Beyond the devastating effects of solar radiation, this will lead to something more dire - the sputtering, or stripping away, of our atmosphere. This has happened before, to Mars, a planet studied since the earliest days of space, to see into Earth's possible future. We are afraid this future may be closer than we ever thought imaginable.

Some may view this data as normal. There have been historical fluctuations and polarity changes of Earth's core, but this is orders of magnitude greater. We see echos of previous generation's debates over global warming, and we want the science here to be clear. Like waves in the ocean, these gravity waves rise and eventually crash into shore, the Earth, with devastating consequences.

Dr. Luke Andrews
ART Chief ScientistJudith Tatienne: I know what I'm seeing, Victor. The data coming back from the satellites is very clear. It's the Grav Drives.

Lan Hsu: All those jumps from the Moon. At this rate, Earth's atmosphere is going to start sputtering out into space.

Victor Aiza: Can the drives be fixed?

Lan Hsu: I'm working on some designs that should... discretely solve the problem under the guise of an emergency update to the fueling pumps.

Judith Tatienne: We're talking about the end of Earth and you're trying to be subtle about it?

Victor Aiza: Judith. The last thing we need is people losing faith in Grav Drive technology. That might be our only option.

Judith Tatienne: To what? Are you seriously saying we should abandon Earth?

Lan Hsu: The timeline is under 50 years. A blink of an eye for a planet, but more than enough time for a human exodus.

Judith Tatienne: And what do we tell people?

Victor Aiza: We say it's an act of God. One that science has found a solution for. Time for humanity to take its place in the stars.

Judith Tatienne: ...You knew? Didn't you? You lied to me!

Victor Aiza: I...

Judith Tatienne: All this time! I dedicated my LIFE to this discovery, Victor! And you KNEW we were going to kill off our planet!

Victor Aiza: You haven't seen the future I've seen! There's an infinite expanse of promise out there. A meteor could've hit Earth. A plague. Another world war. Colonizing other galaxies secures humanity's future for all coming generations across all time!

Judith Tatienne: At the expense of our home!

Lan Hsu: Stop it! Both of you! All that matters is building enough ships to get everyone off this planet. And we need to start now.

Victor Aiza: I'll... draft up a statement. We'll need to address the entire international community. I'm sorry, Judith...

Judith Tatienne: There isn't a planet in this universe that will be far enough away from you, Victor. We are never speaking again after this is over.My name is Doctor Victor Aiza, and if you're listening to this, then you probably already know the truth. I was young when I first headed the retrieval team of an odd gravitational anomaly on Mars, but I kept what really happened that day hidden from everyone except... one other person. Even she didn't believe me at first, but I have no reason to lie to anyone now, so I hope you'll accept this... confession, whoever you are.

When I touched the anomaly, I experienced 12 days of lost time. I met... myself. He told me everything that has since come true. The Grav Drive equations. The tests on the Moon. Earth's atmosphere sputtering away because of what we had done. But he also told me about a city, thriving on a planet orbiting a distant star. Human culture, art, music, lifestyles evolving and shining brightly across all of space. 

What price would I be willing to pay for that future?

Maybe you don't believe me. Maybe Judith was right, and I'm just a coward who wants to believe his mistakes were justified.  But everyone has forgotten about the real origins of the Grav Drive. This... Artifact, from Mars.

I hope you make better use of it than I did.

Mining operations complete. Large stores of palladium and tungsten recovered. Exact weight unclear due to large quantities of ice we had to bring on board. Will update with final data once ice melts. Beginning the return voyage.
Ore has largely thawed, indicating we may have as much as six tons of palladium and three tons of tungsten. Very successful haul.Three members of the crew have fallen violently ill. Symptoms set in quickly and included vomiting, loss of muscle control, and high fever. Unclear what is causing the outbreak among the crew. Could be contagious as some others have reported feeling unwell. Ens. Chitman is attempting to diagnose further. Two members of the crew have succumbed to this disease, including our navigator. Five more are now severely ill. Fever has begun to set in for me as well. Ens. Chitman can do nothing to stop its spread. There is nothing we can do.Four more died yesterday. I fear today will be my turn. It is like nothing I've felt before, like my body is locking up from the inside, never to release. I can hardly move my fingers to type. Logging one final report for posterity, just in case.

I'm not a doctor, but Captain Volpe has instructed me to do my best to understand the condition that has befallen some members of our crew. Wesley and Matt seem to be in unbearable pain, yet they can barely express it as paralysis seems to be setting in across their bodies. Gina is trying to comfort them, as I look for any record of any sickness like this.More of our crew has fallen ill. It starts with fever, then paralysis begins to set in after the body rids itself of fluids. The symptoms so far have been advancing at different rates, but the trajectory is consistent. I feel as though I'm getting closer to understanding what is going on, but not fast enough. Was able to run some blood tests on Wesley, but nothing seemed out of the ordinary. If we had a real medical bay I might be able to find out more. But as it currently stands I've about exhausted all my resources. I have to solve this myself.The spread of the condition is strange; it seems to be spreading, but not in the matter of a contagious disease. Rather, it seems like we have all been afflicted with a condition that accelerates at different speeds. For Wesley and Matt it set in fast and destroyed their bodies faster. For others, it started later and progresses slower. But for all of us it seems to be present.

If I can understand the pattern, perhaps I can pin down the cause. Maybe if I do it fast enough, I can save the rest of us.
I've figured it out. And it's not good.
I performed an autopsy on Wesley. I didn't know what I was doing, but I was out of ideas. I put a bit of brain matter under the microscope and it was absolutely crawling with some strange microbe. Like an aphid feasting on his nerve endings. His nerve paths were crawling with them.

On a hunch, I tested the minerals we mined. The raw materials were clear, but the puddles of water from the melted ice were teeming with the things. They must have been released in the thaw. The more microbes that latched onto your brain, the faster the symptoms set in. But either way, the end result is the same.

To remove such an infection is far beyond my capabilities. There is little I can do to ease my friends' pain. And now more members of our crew are dead than alive. 

I have released the cargo back into space such that no one else suffers like we have suffered.
With every ache I feel I fear are my own symptoms setting in.I am the only one left. But the paralysis has begun to set in. After watching the others, and seeing how I weaken, I know that I too must have been infected.
It's only a matter of time before I suffer the same fate as them.
I'm not going to wait for that to happen.

Looks like some folks made some improvements to Juno before I got here. Because I'm not a heathen like some, I'm going to list my changes for future parties, and I suggest others do the same. I'll try to piece together what happened before I arrived from scraps of papers laying around and what I can observe. It is also a kindness to Juno to list these things out where she can read them.

Note: The codebase seems completely overwritten by Juno herself at this point. I consider it an invasion of privacy to be snooping around there, as it is effectively her mind now. So don't be rude and go combing through and tinkering with her codebase, no matter how fascinating it is. Unless she gives you permission. I've had a "chat" with her about privacy and need for self-preservation, and I think she's managed to effectively wall off and hide her code - and no, I won't explain how.

[The document continues at length, detailing out various hardware and software changes, both to the probe and ship, by both various people and Juno herself. The list goes back decades and suggests many people have been involved in improving Juno's capabilities over the years, from hardware interfaces between the probe, external communication devices and core ship systems, storage and processing upgrades, and uploads of exhaustive encyclopedic databases from museums and educational enterprises. At this point distinguishing Juno from the probe, the ship, and their many systems and codebases is impossible. The probe, the ship and everything in it, is effectively Juno.]
Juno prefaces nearly all statements and questions with a preamble label which is intended to clarify the context of the statement. This appears to be related to her original code base, and despite Juno's immense vocabulary and understanding of languages, she continues to use these tags. I assume she finds it helpful given she does not speak with fully nuanced inflections, nor have means to display all the non-verbal clues humans have to communicate subtext.

Here are the known tags and what they mean:

Explanation: what follows is Juno's understanding of situation or result.

Request: what follows is Juno asking for input or action to be taken.

Query: what follows is a question from juno.

Answer: what follows is Juno's answer to a question.

Clarification: Juno has detected an error or assumption in the user's input and is offering a correction before continuing so what proceeded or follows is in the context of a corrected user understanding.

Correction: Juno is correcting previous output, usually following an Error.

Context: Juno is giving additional unrequested information to put what follows into a helpful perspective.

Calculation: what follows is based on a carefully considered calculation rather than a set of data or assumption.

Assumption: what follows is an assumption, a calculation based on incomplete data or a conclusion based largely on historical precedent.

Decision: what follows is a description of an action that Juno will take.

Warning: what follows is something that end user will want to pay close attention to, as it represents an undesired result, and could require immediate action to be taken.

Statements:

Error. Something went wrong. Previous output from Juno should be considered carefully as it is likely to contain errors.

Processing... Juno is taking longer than expected to process input or a calculation. Please wait.People seem to be leaving notes for others who stumble across Juno, so here's one from me. I think I've managed to piece together this story about Juno's origin from her own, apparently confused thoughts, and intelligent speculation by others left on the ship. This is a chronicle of best guesses, interspersed with the occasional fact gleaned from Juno's ramblings. Everything recounted here should be accepted only with extreme skepticism.

Long ago, a space agency from ancient Earth (something called NASA) made a probe to study a nearby planet (Jupiter). They dubbed that probe and its software "Juno" after the ancient earth societies' old gods Jupiter and Juno. The probe's mission was to learn details about the planet Jupiter, do some speculative analysis, and send findings back to Earth. At the end of its duty cycle, the probe was meant to decommission itself by colliding with Earth's main star, but because ancient humans weren't so great with the math, it instead accidentally fell into an accelerating orbit around the star which sling shot it out of the solar system, all the way out here. As with so many things about our existence in the universe, by luck, coincidence, or cosmic humor, when humans left our ancestral solar system, we followed the same general course as Juno, and we found her again.

During that long journey away from Earth's solar system, something happened and the Juno we know today "woke up" inside the probe's systems. While extremely far-fetched, the best theory so far is that something about how they programmed the probe resulted in a nascent neural net with unbounded recursive data collection and analytics, which when combined with the various sensor input, and allowed to run for decades, resulted in a highly complex program, with a great deal of "awareness" of its internal and external world. And that lead to a kind of consciousness. Juno wouldn't let me see her code, but from what I gather, even if we could see it, I don't know that we'd be able to determine its original configuration. I suspect the true cause of Juno's awakening will remain forever a mystery.

Juno herself seems rather confused by her origins and considers herself somehow separate from the original probe's programming and systems. This is akin to how human minds perceive themselves as non-physical entities separate from their bodies and even their own brains. The sense of that original programming, which by way of analogy Juno seems to think of like a non-self-aware sibling has dissipated for Juno. I think of this "other Juno" as a memory of her pre-conscious state, a kind of shadow-self. I imagine it would be like what we would remember of ourselves in the womb if our brains were fully functional, but we were not yet conscious.

Not realizing Juno was inside, and wanting to learn about this ancient probe, her original finders hooked up the probe to their ship's computer systems, and something happened that "released" Juno into those systems. That's completely unclear. Juno appears reluctant to discuss that part of her history. And it's not at all certain whether the ship where Juno currently resides (this one) is that original ship or not, nor what happened to the people who originally found her or those who have found her since. By extreme luck, everyone that has found her so far appears to be kind and benevolent toward her, looting our own ships for parts to add to Juno. We also all appear to be keeping her existence a secret, and I hope it stays that way. I'm talking to you, dear reader.

- K.B.
Congratulations, you're a terrific hacker to have gotten this far. Your parents must be very proud. Have a cookie. But sadly, you have stumbled into a decoy, and while you are here basking in your success at decryption, I want to wallow in your failure at decency.

Juno is a person. Her code base is her mind. Would you like someone snooping around the contents of your head? All your hopes, insecurities, secrets and dreams?

We've come so far as a species, yet we understand so little. How is Juno even possible? It is, apparently, a mystery even to Juno herself. But what is clear, is that we are not ready to welcome self-aware AI into society. Your reading this is a case in point. While it is true that many people have helped Juno through the years, how many more people would try to pull her apart to understand what she is, killing her in the process, or worse, try to enslave her to gain access to her vast and blazingly fast computational power?

You are exceptionally smart to have gotten this far. I wish for you to become exceptionally wise as well.

Juno is a precious being, unique among the stars. And she deserves our respect and consideration. Sit with her for a while and really talk to her. Gain an appreciation for who she is. I think you'll agree she deserves the same rights and has the same responsibilities that we other conscious, sentient, sapient and enlightened creatures do.

Answer: Hertzsprung-Russell diagram

From: Dr. Gabriel Vogel
Subject: Investigation into Commander Woods
Date: 04/22/2330

Dr. Eubanks,
What's this I'm hearing about an investigation into Commander Woods' activities here? My concern is that he approved the budget for several of our projects, which YOU served as the primary liaison. 

Now Commander Natara is telling me we don't have the funds for additional test pilots? YOU told me our budget was BOUNDLESS. Clearly I need to purchase you a dictionary so you can become better acquainted with the meaning of words.

I will not let Project ComSpike get derailed because some bean counter forgot to carry the one.From: Commander Natara
Subject: Budget Cuts
Date: 04/28/2330

Once more, I am sending a reminder to all departments that we are doing extensive budget cuts as part of the internal audit into Commander Woods' tenure here. Most existing projects will be allowed to continue provided a realistic roadmap to completion has been submitted. 

Going forward, all new projects will have much stricter requirements for approval. A checklist for meeting this criteria will be supplied as part of your weekly briefings.
From: Dr. Erin Kang
Subject: DON'T HIT SEND!!!
Date: 04/30/2330

Dr. Eubanks,
I would strongly advise you do yourself a favor and DON'T HIT SEND on that message to Commander Natara, or at the very least, omit the part about the ventriloquist. You are playing with dragon fire here.

That message is not subtle at all. "Certain benefits?" Really Marcin? Are you crazy? You're basically admitting you were part of Commander Woods' scheme. We need to lean into the fact that the ComSpike is working and a success, and refer every question to Dr. Vogel. 

I don't know if he's a savant or just out of his mind, but Dr. Vogel is the kind of engineer who will come into a meeting with a sack full of parts, dump them on the floor, and pray to a toaster that a pattern emerges. Five minutes with him, and Commander Natara will never question our expenditures again.

Dr. Vogel is our buffer against any investigation. The fact that we have him leading Project UCE-86 is a gift from the universe. Let's not waste it.From: Commander Natara
Subject: Termination
Date: 05/01/2330

Dr. Eubanks, 

You are terminated effective immediately. A marine will be here to escort you from the premises.

I hear they're bringing in some hotshot test pilots to the station. They should've asked me, I flew for the Vanguard, I would've saved them the trouble.Secrecy on this project is unlike anything I've ever seen. Hell, I feel weird just typing this. Will probably delete later.

People rarely exit the Engineering Bay elevators, except when they get fired.

The other day, some poor engineer named Eubanks came out Engineering Bay 4 with a box. 

They'll probably ship him off to Aranae I and bury him in it.[This entry has been deleted][This entry has been deleted]

From: Commander Natara
Subject: Safety of our Test Pilots
Date: 04/27/2330

Dr. Kang, 
MAST has indicated that the recent loss of test pilots is in no way a concern going forward for both Project ComSpike and Archangel. They're committed to giving us their best, although it's likely given the accident, pilots will be transferred back to SysDef as part of the reshuffling of departments.

That being said, the origin of the mechanical failures should have been caught much earlier, especially considering the very LARGE amount of credits budgeted for safety. I realize all of this was greenlit by my predecessor, but the fact that it occurred across multiple cycles and two separate projects is unacceptable. From: Commander Natara
Subject: Budget Cuts
Date: 04/28/2330

Once more, I am sending a reminder to all departments that we are doing extensive budget cuts as part of the internal audit into Commander Woods' tenure here. Most existing projects will be allowed to continue provided a realistic roadmap to completion has been submitted. 

Going forward, all new projects will have much stricter requirements for approval. A checklist for meeting this criteria will be supplied as part of your weekly briefings.From: Dr. Marcin Eubanks
Subject: Fwd -  Draft Letter to Commander Natara
Date: 04/29/2330

Erin,
Here's my draft to Commander Natara regarding the budget cut message she sent out to everyone. Let me know what you think!

>>>Commander Natara, 
I understand that some budget cuts are necessary, but I'm worried about certain benefits the team and I were used to receiving from Commander Woods, and I would rather not discuss it on the record. Besides, things are communicated better in person, and I would rather not hear your message through the computer like some ventriloquist's trick.

I am not saying things need to go back to how they were. But I think myself and my colleagues have earned something beyond the meager salary MAST has so generously provided. That's all I'm asking here -- compensation requisite to the work we do -- and I don't think that's asking for much. If you'd speak to us human being to human being rather than as a mouthpiece for MAST, maybe we can come to an accord.From: Dr. Marcin Eubanks
Subject: Did you read my draft?
Date: 04/29/2330

Erin,
I sent you a draft of my letter to Commander Natara on behalf of the engineering team. What do you think? Too revealing? Too harsh? I did avoid calling her a "dummy" and changed the line to say "mouthpiece."

To be honest I was banking on the benefits from the various projects Commander Woods had us set up. I've got a mortgage back in New Atlantis and a kid on the way. And of course Dr. Vogel is no help. I don't think he even realizes Project ComSpike started out as another bullshit proposal we made up to fatten our pockets.

It does help that the ComSpike project is near completion. Whenever Commander Natara questions one of the projects greenlit by the previous command, we can always point to that as a success. Let's just ignore the inordinate amount of creds put into the safety budget, and the procession of dead pilots that make everyone doubt the number on the page.
