The incident with Project Archangel highlights two areas of concern, with both the safety of the projects and the smuggling of contraband to SY-920. 

At some point, we should probably do a full audit of all cargo ships authorized to dock. Commander Woods poured money into two tentpole items: safety and security. But the safety record for our projects is terrible, and the leaks to outside sources prove security was not up to standard.

Now we've swung in the opposite direction, and it's been a welcome adjustment. Commander Natara has put in multiple checkpoints and security measures that will help safeguard the sensitive nature of the projects here.

In any case, I'll need to put together a proper report on potential smugglers before presenting to Commander Natara. She doesn't like it when I make suggestions off the cuff. The list is daunting, unfortunately, given the supplies we need. Another spreadsheet for the pile.After staring at this spreadsheet for hours, I've decided to cull the list down to a handful of ships that may be suspect. 

This is not proof of guilt by any means, they simply match the criteria I've laid down to narrow my search. Mainly, ships that began as independent contractors not directly associated with the United Colonies, and ships that have less than a decade of operational history we can refer to.

In the list are:

Ship: Anansi UC-576B, Cargo Class Transport
Captain: Malawi Ndiaye

Ship: Jade Swan UC-793A, Cargo Class Transport
Captain: Huan Daiyu

Ship: Clair de Lune UC-887C, Cargo Class Transport
Captain: Finneas Kimball

Ship: Izanagi UC-996C, Cargo Class Transport
Captain: Kazuhiro Sakaniwa

I wonder if it's possible that one of the transports I've flagged is the source of our operations leak. I'll need to cross-reference the delivery dates with the ones on my spreadsheet, maybe there's some correlation there.

But right now even I have to admit there's just not enough evidence. Commander Natara dismissed my initial report as lacking anything concrete. "As thin as the slate it was written on," she said.

To be fair, I can tell she's under a lot of pressure. Commander Woods still has some loyalists on this station, and any misstep will subvert her authority.

I keep forgetting to check the computer in the security room before going through the checkpoint.

I've got a bit of an astigmatism too, which seems to manifest itself whenever I'm looking at lines of text. So sometimes I'll look at the code for the wrong rank, or the wrong surname, and I'll get denied entrance to the Operations Center.I knew this was coming. Commander Natara read me the riot act for always being the last one in to report. She's not wrong. In the marines, if you aren't five minutes early, you're ten minutes late.

Funny part is, I'm actually the first one to leave the barracks. But it's the damn codes. I always screw those up. Also, I hate to beat a dead horse, but we never had all these procedures under Commander Woods, but he's been disappeared for reasons that remain classified.
I guess I shouldn't be surprised. I got transferred to logistics because of my issues being punctual. 

While having to sit in a cubicle all day is pretty depressing, on the bright side, at least I don't need a clearance code to sit at my desk.

Whatever projects are being worked on here must be incredibly important. Keycards at every elevator, checkpoints on every floor.

The COs don't tell us anything except when to eat, patrol, and sleep. Fine by me. The less I know, the fewer secrets I have to keep.What is Ensign Palavi doing that requires him to type ALL day? 

The worst part is he has one of those annoying, one finger typing techniques that is the equivalent of paint drying in zero gravity. 

Is he writing a novel? Because no single military report requires that much typing. He's made it so I can't even think, because all I do is rage.

Well, two can play at that game. I'm just going to type loudly and self-importantly until he can no longer keep the chapters in his story straight.

No great fiction will be written by your hand tonight, Ensign Palavi. Not if I can help it.AKL;JSDKJL;SDJKL;SDFKML,32DSOI;UVMNDSXSC8932JKRSRDIUOFASDKLAWSDFVCOIPCSOIKASdFIJUHDkiopjfsdkfsadf98p3eam,d98pQEJWFSDJKENKMSNKJCLNCKLNKSKNLFDKALNDOI;HE98PWEIO;3KJ;LN3NJK;L3NJKL;DSFNOI;SD90838903KL3IHUJDSNKLFDAJKH;DM,NDKMDSNKLSDFNLK;JFDSANKL;FDNKL;FAKNL;FDN;LKJFDSN;KLJFDSN;KJLFDWAN;LKJFDASN;LKJFDSANKL;FDSNK;LFDSANK;LFDSANK;LAFDSNKLFDASKLF98032KM3M,CI98934IKL23890Fdskjl"SDZFI98FJWEK,9PUIYPFUSZDJKLVCNXIOPUDSIFKASDDIO;AFDSKFDAJIO;;oi3489a;jahugfyufghnczby8OS78HAOFSD87A34HADUSIFH78uswajdaulhfdsjfna3879pUJHDSJFHO8PUSIDHf789y3hoaH87FhpHOS78oh78YDFHOuldhf78oHDFuhdfO789dyhfuIHFO8hDOF87yPDo879HDFJBXCKZBZ.KZO8z98DJIFLAHD87OAHDUFHA87FHAUDH7O8hLUIHL87fhdsufhaudho78HDUFAHDUH897FA7D8oHFAOU8DHFO78A9DHFAUOIDFH78OOUHFDUSAO8HFDO8S7Houhfo78HO8dhfudshaijdhfnjabnvujizhafj;aisdfhjasdufhadsyufhsakdjfhdsufjadsiohf8P9Hpaudhfauodhfaliueyuh2n3jhaudfhHuhdaopudfhsajifhadslijdhauidfhadujifhadsuifhdajifhdasuijfndasufhadsufadju9fdhafjidhaliudhfulaishflaiudfhodah89YH73RHUAIDHF8oudhP9121982321J;3N2ILUHP98DNFJIHADFALIFHDDDSFFA9

I was talking to another marine about some of the projects on this station, and we both concluded we don't know a damn thing about them. I get that operation security is always integral to a successful mission, but usually the circle of trust extends to the jarheads working the perimeter.

But here - especially on the Command Bay level - we can't even put on our pants without an access card. I can't imagine how restrictive it must be in Engineering.My wife thought the transfer to logistics would do me some good, and I can't say I disagree. I've done enough combat tours to write my own personal war trilogy and so it's good to have some R&R.

The slow days are a killer though. There must be a black hole nearby the way time moves here. When this tour is over, I'll probably come back home and find the missus old and gray.Okay, now I'm officially bored. This is a high level mission with top secret clearance and all of that, but those are the jobs that see the least amount of action. The hard-working people in UC Intelligence make sure of that.

So I'm not sure what to do when I'm done filing my daily inactivity report. 

Maybe I will write that novel.

I know as an engineer, packaging falls out of my purview, but I would like to report that some of the packaging from the last few shipments has fallen short of the UC standard. This may be anecdotal, but I opened a crate the other day and a terminal was inside without any foam, wrap, or cushioning.

It paints a gruesome picture, I'm sure. A terminal, rattling around in a box, grav jumping across time and space, with no protective barrier to absorb the shock. It's a minor miracle the screen wasn't cracked. I asked the crew who packed the boxes, and they just shrugged and told me to take it up with MAST. Which is unacceptable.

I've heard some of the haulers don't like Ms. Daiyu because she's not very chatty, but at least everything she delivers is professionally packed.

-- AbloniErm... not to rat him out, but I think Elijah lost his SY-920 Maintenance Keycard. Again. Every time I ask him to grab something from the utility room he makes up some excuse, which gets more and more ridiculous every time I ask.

This time he said Commander Natara wanted him to measure the lugnuts in a toolbox to make sure they were "no greater than 3 cm in diameter in accordance with The Treaty of Narion." I didn't want to be the bad guy and tell him that's not what the treaty says, but I think he knows that already.

I know this is gonna sound mean, but can we put in a requisition to have the keycard stapled to his forehead? I'm seriously getting tired of him losing it.

-- Marquez

May 6th, 2330

Maybe I shouldn't even be writing this here, but I need to get it off my chest somehow.

The date with Leah didn't go well. At all.

I think we spent three hours together, of which she spent two hours and fifty-eight minutes telling me about how great Solomon Coe was. She could have just told me she was already in love and saved me the embarrassment.

Of course, Helga's going to ask how it went, and I have to think carefully about what to say, since she's the one who set up the date.

Maybe I'll just stay single like the Marshal. It's less complicated, anyway.
May 4th, 2330

I can't focus on anything today. I'm just a ball of nerves. Why did I let Helga set me up on that date?

Is Leah beautiful? Yes. Is she smart? Very. Am I totally smitten? Maybe.

Do I feel even remotely ready for this date? NO.

What do I wear? What will we talk about? Am I going to bore her to death because all I know is Ranger work and cryptography?

Can I stop writing pointless journal entries filled with rhetorical questions and get back to work?April 30th, 2330

Some genius in the Shaw Gang decided that they should start using codes to communicate. Diego brought me one of their slates, and the cipher was so simple, I actually burst out laughing right in the middle of the cantina. Almost made Emma spit out her drink.

When will they learn? Maybe I should tell them to up their game and at least TRY to give me challenge.

To: Alex Shadid
From: Helga Dubray
Subject: Fingers crossed!

Tonight's the big night! I hope you're excited.

Now, remember what I said - don't be nervous! You're a great guy and I'm sure it'll go really well. You and Leah are the two smartest people I know, so I have no doubt you'll find a lot to talk about.

You've got this!

To: All Rangers
Subject: New syndicate in play?
From: Daniel Blake

I want you all to keep your eyes and ears open. I've been going over reports from local security both here and in Neon, and there's a disturbing trend. Seems like smuggling is on the rise in a big way, and there's more than one faction involved.

Seems like we might have a new player looking to move in. We can probably expect to see some inter-faction conflict that could spill over and put innocent lives at risk. If you learn anything that could be useful, let me know right away. Autumn's already looking into it, but leads are scarce so far.
To: All Rangers
From: Emma Wilcox
Subject: Another false alarm

Just so you all know, that report we got about the farm on Polvo turned out to be another false alarm. Local security says they headed out to take a look, and the man they talked to said nothing was wrong. Funny thing is, the original call came in from a woman and when security asked to talk to her, the man who they'd met said she went off-world to visit family. 

Normally I wouldn't think twice about it, but I'd read a similar report only a month earlier, where the call had come in from an elderly man, only local security didn't see anyone that old, and when they asked they were told he'd gone on a vacation.

Could be nothing, I know, but if anyone hears about trouble on a farm, let me know. Couldn't hurt to check it out.

To: Alex Shadid
From: Diego Monroe
Subject: Shepherd was looking for you

Shepherd was here looking for you. He said your shipment of components and cryptography slates came in, and you can pick them up during shop hours.
To: All Rangers
From: Emma Wilcox
Subject: Good news

For those who haven't heard, we got some good news. The doc has approved Helga for limited duty on-site here at the Rock. With some luck, she'll be back in the field in a few weeks, but we want to take things slow and take all the necessary precautions. 

In the meantime, let's all give her some encouragement and support. No Ranger wants to be stuck indoors while there are people out there who need our help, but sometimes that's the way it's got to be. I know you'll all be there for her while she heals up.
To: All Rangers
From: Daniel Blake
Subject: Recruiting

I know you've all heard me say it before, but the Council would really like to see us bolster our ranks, so here's my obligatory reminder to keep a look out for anyone you think might be Ranger material. There's fewer of us now than there have been since I joined up, and I don't have to tell you all that was a long damn time ago.

Fact is, the Freestar Collective ain't exactly getting safer by the day. There's always been more trouble than there's been Rangers to handle it, but that's more true now that it ever has been. We need more help, and we need it soon.

May 6th, 2330

Serves me right for getting my hopes up. I was all set to get back to work, and the doc says she won't approve me for field duty.

I feel fine! I'm not even sore anymore, and my breathing's more than good enough to work. Hell, the job's mostly just flying from place to place and talking to people.

It's bad enough I was laid up in bed for so long. I guess the wait is always worst right at the end. Whatever it is, I'm totally stir crazy here. Poor doc, I'm probably driving her crazy.

Just need to hold it together a little longer.May 4th, 2330

Can't stop smiling today. Why, you ask? (Of course, I realize I'm basically talking to myself here, but I've earned a little gloating.)

Because Leah agreed to go on a date with Alex! Yes, my months-long project has finally come to fruition, and love is surely in the air.

If this works out, I think I'll ask them to name one of their inevitable kids after me. 

Well, maybe not if it's a boy. Maybe then it'd have to be a similar name, like... Helgo or Helborg.

On second thought, no, those are terrible.April 20th, 2330

There are moments in your life that make you stop and really think about what you've got.

For me, one of those moment came about three seconds before my crash-landing. I didn't know if I'd survive. It really felt like a 50-50 shot.

What I remember the most about that moment is just an overwhelming feeling of gratitude, for this job, for the other Rangers, and for every inch of this big, ugly, smelly, wonderful town I call home.

Note to self - never, ever lose that feeling of gratitude. In fact, that's my new life goal - die smiling.

To: Helga Dubray
From: Mary Cartwright
Subject: Latest test results

Helga,

Some good news and some you won't like, but I want to focus on the good. You're making great progress in your recovery. In fact, you're ahead of schedule. Whatever you're doing, keep it up!

Unfortunately, I'm still not ready to approve you for a return to field duty. I know that's not what you wanted to hear, but there's still the risk of a setback or complication, and I want to be on hand in the event something comes up.

Just stay the course and be patient. All signs point to you being back in the field sooner rather than later.

Heard you're finally up and about. Like they say, any landing you can walk away from, right?

You take it easy. I know this recovery is going to drive you crazy. If you need to blow off some steam, I'm here. We can do a little Ashta target practice on the wall if you want. Or just grab a beer and talk about the Marshal behind his back. Whatever it takes.

Get well soon, hermanita.

Surgery was a success. Vitals are good. A-10 only complained about the food, so we ran some extra tests on taste and smell to be safe. Results came back normal. I can't blame him. The food here is lackluster.

Incision seals are holding. Hoping the next few observations days are nice and quiet.Vitals are still holding with no sign of rejection. A-10 behavior appears completely normal.First day of testing. A-10 was able to influence Subject B-1 to sit in a chair and pick up a slate. B-1 reported disorientation and confusion that lasted for the duration of the test and approximately fifteen minutes later. Vitals and cognition testing were all normal.

A-10 reported a severe headache, specifically where the neuroamp is implanted. Started A-10 on standard pain management regimen.

UPDATE: Upping pain management to include stronger anti-inflammatory medication. Scans indicated swelling at the neuroamp location. Detected brain hemorrhaging in early morning scans, and Dr. Lane performed emergency surgery to remove the neuroamp. A-10 is currently in a coma and has been placed in a med pod for monitoring and basic life support. Brain swelling has gone down, but there is significant scarring. A-10's overall condition hasn't worsened. If he does wake up, Dr. Lane estimates an 85% chance of permanent damage.

Personal Logs Not AvailableLog Entry UCES03-0001
Morgan, Sarah, Cmdr, UCN78422ES

It's been two days since my crash-landing on Cassiopeia I. I've been slipping in and out of consciousness, but I've been able to use emergency meds to keep my pain levels to a minimum. Medical self-assessment has revealed three cracked ribs, a broken forearm, a minor concussion, probable internal damage and a hell of a lot of bruises. I'll do the best that I can to push through, but I can't allow my injuries to keep me from reaching Shuttle 02.

Tomorrow I plan to do a full reconnoiter of the area and search for some high ground to place my distress beacon. With any luck, some ships are still in orbit, and they'll receive my signal. For now, I'm going to rest, eat a bit of my food rations and pray that the other shuttle isn't too far from my location.Log Entry UCES03-0007
Morgan, Sarah, Cmdr, UCN78422ES

Using the telemetry data and geomapping charts I had in my slate, I was able to track exactly where Shuttle 02 went down. Unfortunately, it appears to be located several thousand kilometers away, making it impossible to reach on foot. Even if the planet was hospitable and the terrain accommodating, I'm in no physical condition to even attempt such a journey. Additionally, with my distress beacon and all my supplies located at this crash site, I don't dare leave it behind.

I'm afraid my crew will have to deal with whatever hardships they've encountered on their own. All I can do at this point is pray they're safe.Log Entry UCES03-0014
Morgan, Sarah, Cmdr, UCN78422ES

It's been nearly a month, and I'm down to my final three power cells. If I want to make them last, I'm going to have to disconnect them from my ship's computer system, which means I lose access to my computer and my short-range transmitter. If Shuttle 02 makes any attempt to reach out for me, all they're going to receive is silence.

It's a horrible decision to have to make, but if Shuttle 02 hasn't contacted me by now, it's unlikely that they ever will. I don't know if that means their com system is simply damaged or if they've left their crash site, or if they're even alive. My only hope is continuing to power the distress beacon in hopes of being picked up and then searching for them from the air.

Well. Here we are again. Another "rare mineral contract." 

This time, it's sulfur. You remember sulfur, don't you? Dangerous, flammable, rife with gas plumes that'll melt the seals in your suit before you have a chance to scream? Literal brimstone.

It also happens to be the 10th most common mineral in the whole freaking universe. I don't think there's a miner in this crew that actually believes we came all the way to House Va'ruun's doorstep to mine this stuff. "Rare mineral" my tail.

But Barrett and his New Atlantean social club paid for discretion. So we're mining sulfur. 

And praying to the heavens this "anomaly" they're actually after turns up before anyone gets hurt. Twenty days working three shifts a day. That's how long it took to get this sham facility set up to mine this stinking yellow dreck. Sinking the supports alone took the better part of a week, just to make sure we didn't trigger a gas rupture and kill everyone before we began.

The amount of money this Constellation group is spending must be astronomical. The scanning technology alone looks like it was stolen from a UC skunkworks. Whatever this anomaly is, it must be worth a fortune.

Though if it is that valuable, it'd explain why they don't want anyone to know they're looking for it in the first place.Our first emergency evac today. One of the dusties dug where he shouldn't have and got a sulfur dioxide spray down. His helmet held, but his seals melted to nothing. 

Foreman was able to get him back to the hab before he asphyxiated, but he was in rough shape. We stabilized, and I had Heller jump him back to the nearest medical facility... fifty-plus light-years away in Akila. Sounds like he's going to live and is expected to make a full recovery.

I hope Barrett's people sprung for the good insurance.I'm sitting here, writing this, so I can give my heartrate time to come down from the high four figures.

We had a vessel alarm today. I'm guessing Heller's trip to Akila and back drew some attention from the neighbors: a ship full of Va'ruun Zealots.

Most of the crew was out in Shaft A when the alarm sounded, with just me and Jenkins in the facility. I immediately called a work stop and full radio silence, then ran, top speed, to the gennies to shut them down. Then, Jenkins and I ran, holding our breath, to our suits, and barely managed to stash ourselves outside under a catwalk, just as the first of the Zealots came up the steps.

The first - presumably their captain - walked right over our heads, some alien firearm trained on the airlock where we'd just been. I've never gotten that close to a Zealot before. Their suits are covered in these wrapped patterns. Makes them look... well, barely human. And the battle scarring made it clear he'd walked away from his fair share of raids before.

And it was right at that moment, as this Zealot warrior is standing directly on top of us, that Jenkins... hiccups.

The captain freezes. Turns. Looks straight at his second.

"Silence."

I think they really bought the place was abandoned. They came in, took some rations, ammo, the couple firearms we had. And they left.

And, for me, this illustrates three necessities we've got before us:

1. We need more guns and better training with them.
2. We need to find this anomaly yesterday.
3. I'm going to launch Jenkins into a star the moment an opportunity presents itself.We found it! Hallelujah, at long last, we found it!

Up until today, we'd been looking for a mineral anomaly. A piece of metal or rock that stood out from the things around it.

But today, Jenkin's replacement noticed something odd on one of the seismometers we've placed around to warn in case of gas rupture - it seemed like there was a dip in gravity right near the mouth of Shaft A.

Scans of the spot showed the exact signature we'd been told to look for.

So, extraction at this point gets tricky. I'm going to need folks to move over there, then convince them all they're digging into a gas vein to get them to leave the area the hell alone.

And while they're working on that, I've got to collect Barrett. Then we can finally get off this god-forsaken rock.
It's done. The anomaly's found and in our employer's possession. I escorted Barrett to the site personally, and the two of us went down to collect.

Or, at least, that was the intention. Once we hit the mouth of the cave, Barrett turned to me and said, "Could be dangerous down there. Why don't you head back to the hab?"

Dangerous? You don't say! But the customer's always right blah, blah, so I turned back and waited in the facility with the crew.

And so we waited.

And waited. 

And waited.

After what seemed like several hours, he finally comes stumbling back through the airlock, looking like he'd seen ghost, but grinning ear to ear. He claimed he'd found what he was looking for. but that he'd sucked down a little too much sulfur while he was down there, and passed out.

He was obviously lying. Something happened. But if it meant we could, at long last, get the hell out of here, I wasn't about to argue.All the transportable equipment's been off-worlded and the rest isn't worth the credits it'd take to get it out of here.

Congratulations, Constellation. You've added an ugly couple scars to one of the foulest worlds I've ever had the displeasure of working on.

And if I never hear from these people again, it'll be too soon.
You have (0) progress reports that require attention.

I can't wait for my time off. I booked this incredible package that's going to take me to some extraordinary places! It was incredibly cheap and apparently a little dangerous but I live for the excitement.

I've been floating around in this hunk of junk for so long anything is better than here.That went by way too fast! What an experience... At one point we actually got to spend the night out under the stars in this amazing alien swamp. I woke up covered in these weird leech things which was kind of messed up, but hey, when else am I ever going to get to experience something like that?!So a few days after my time off I started feeling kind of itchy. It's not really that bad, sort of feels like a dull burning sensation on my scalp. I found an antibiotic cream in a first aid kit which I'm hoping will do the trick.

This should make for a pretty funny story to tell the crew back home haha.Well the cream didn't work, and I haven't slept in what feels like maybe 4 days. I swear it feels like something is trying to eat its way into my brain. I changed course to the nearest settlement with a medical facility, I'm sure they'll know what to do.AHHH I CAN'T TAKE IT! MAKE IT STOP! THE VOICES!! ARRGGHHHHHHH

DO NOT release these robots! These Model A's are from a Freestar freighter we jumped near  Cheyenne. Two bots were defending the ship. It took us an hour to hack in and put them to sleep.

Donny thinks he can re-code them to do chores around the station. So unless that's your name, STOP NOW! If they wake up, these robots will attack on sight.

We should stop capturing UC ships for a while. We can still sell their loot in Akila, but if the UNC realizes that this station exists, I'm not sure how long we could hide from them. That's definitely attention we don't need.

We should make preparations, in case we need to defend ourselves. I'll talk with Sandra about equiping some of our captured ships for combat.Jayce and his crew hijacked a GalBank transport ship. It's the kind of score you dream of. There was a giant safe on board - VIP customer storage and whatnot. They hauled the whole thing back here. Smart.

Unfortunately, Jayce demanded he keep the entire safe for himself. Not smart. So Jayce...is no longer aboard this station. 

Now, the safe stays in the storage area downstairs. I keep the key in this room at all times.

WARNING: You have ONE hour to comply before Admin override.Doriane,

You must've thought I was crazy, but now you see, right? Of all the people I could've chosen - I know you will fill the role of Mantis the best.

In these computers you will find the history of the Mantis. What the Mantis is today, it wasn't always the case. When reading the logs about the first Mantis - don't judge her too harshly. It was a volatile time and before she passed the mantle she recognized that the Mantis could be more than an opportunity to make money. It could be a symbol.

Make the Settled Systems safer. Strike fear into the heart of those that believe they are above the law, above reproach. But most importantly - keep the secrets safe.

Now I'm off to retirement. Don't try to contact me, you won't be able to find me. I've left all you need here.

-The Former MantisI've been forced to take lives before. But this was the first time I did so as the Mantis. It felt different. I was scared, more about letting everyone down than the fight itself. 

At one point the Mantis's ship, the Razorleaf, was light years above everyone else, and she still flies well and true but it's clear I need to upgrade pretty much everything inside it. The hull's what matters, though, that's the symbol.

But in the end, I got the better of Redderer. I imagine there will be celebrations in the streets of Akila City. Total scum. But I can't shake the feeling that Tracker work is at its heart murder for pay. I'm not sure why the old Mantis chose me. But pretty much every Mantis has said that.

-DVI've been going through the motions of living, fighting, and carrying on. But all I can think of is: "You have a year to live, Dory." It plays over and over in my head. I can smell the office. See the sad flat eyes of the doctor. Details come back to me at the oddest times. It puts everything in stark relief. What's important, what's not.

The most important thing is choosing the right successor. And I just know Leon could do it. I have failed him so much. The job always seemed so pressing. If I'm brutally honest with myself, the nannies and the boarding schools raised him more than I. But there is greatness in him, if only he could see it.

I'm going to talk with my lawyer first thing when I get in system. The wheels need to be set in motion. I'm having a good day today. I feel so normal. But I'm walking through the whole world like it's a cloud.

-DV

Dr. Cassidy claimed that a patient in the VIP wing became confrontational and threatened violence when he tried to administer a medication. I spoke to the patient, Catalina Rivera, and calmed her down. She agreed to take the medication.Filed by: P. Taro, security staff
Incident reporter: Rebecca Armistead, RN

Nurse Armistead filed a report that a patient in the VIP was found in an off-limits area. Patient identified as Catalina Rivera was found to be inside a CERV shuttle and was asked to return to her room. Patient cooperated and apologized, expaining she had become lost.Filed by: J. Walsh, security staff
Incident reporter: Candace Doolin, patient (filed complaint)

Patient filed a complaint and insisted on speaking to security about a lack of personalized attention and to inform us that her symptoms were not being taken seriously enough. I informed the patient that was a medical matter and not a security issue. Patient said she was aware of that, but did not feel the medical staff were listening to her concerns and had nowhere left to turn. Spent an hour listening to the patient, which seemed to calm her down.

Don't forget to put in that vacation request. It's been too long since we had a break. Can't wait until we have some quiet time at the cabin on Montara Luna. I'm going to fish all day, and then at night, well, you'll see.

Love you.That last courier ship from Akila brought a slate for you. You were out of your office so I left it on your desk. 
To all staff,

We've had a few recent incidents of personnel entering in the VIP wing without authorization. Please respect the privacy of our VIP guests and DO NOT enter the VIP wing without express authorization, no matter what. See me if you have questions.Did you hear about the bank heist in Akila City? I just read about it on a news slate. I hope nobody we know was hurt or killed. Sounds like the Shaw Gang was behind it, no surprise there. I sure don't miss living on Akila. I'll never take the peace and quiet of the Clinic for granted again.

Dr. Kendrick Lane,

Welcome to the Infinity LTD fold. We hope you'll find the breakthrough research we need to perfect Project Dominion. You came highly recommend by Faye Sengsavahn, our head of Research and Development, so we're very excited to have you with us.

I understand your concerns on these human trials being unauthorized, but I assure you, this is just a minor hiccup. I've been told we're only a few days away from approval, and we'll get those documents to you as soon as possible.

Please remember that all subjects have signed waivers accepting the risks. I hope this will ease any hestitation you may have. The end will justify the means.

Lucas Drexler
CEO: Infinity LTDProject Dominion requires a compatible alloy that the human brain will not reject when the Internal Neuroamp is surgically implanted.

Goal 1: Find the correct alloy ratio
     * A series of metals have been provided for a wide range of experimentation.
     * We're currently looking into obtaining a rare metal to be delivered at a later date.

Goal 2: Ensure the effectiveness of the internal neuroamp
     * Once implantation is successful, ensure the neuroamp can be used effectively.
     * No side effects should be detected for either the user or the target.

Goal 3: Minimize casualties
     * Infinity LTD understands that severe injuries and even fatalities may be encountered. 
     * Do not let issues hinder research progress. Notify your contact and we'll take care of it.

Kai's results were initially so promising, but now the poor kid is in a coma. I thought, surely, he would be the light at the end of this grisly tunnel. We've now gone through our entire list of subjects, and I dread the idea that Infinity will just sign up more.

What is going on over there? Has Faye completely lost her mind? I understand when corporations rush things when it comes to household products or maybe office software, but not something that will endanger the lives of others. This Internal Neuroamp may as well be a murder weapon, and I'm the one with blood on my hands. 

Contracts aside, I'm certain this will end in ruin. It's hard to believe I once walked into the Clinic with high hopes of what Sean and I would bring about. The concept of the Internal Neuroamp from Faye and promises of fame and fortune provided all the motivation I needed. It blinded me. 

I never should've agreed to start the trials without proper approvals. I never should've dragged Sean into this. 

I see now why it was always such a struggle to get my own approvals for human trials. I also see why the contracts are so complex. I never thought I'd lose a patient on my watch, and here I've lost more than I wish to say. Infinity's legal team has assured me that the contracts the subjects signed keep us clear from any legal repercussions, but since the trial itself is still unapproved, I have a feeling they've little to stand on.

But somehow, the hopefulness remains. After the initial losses, I told myself no more, but Faye would insist her changes to the prototype were solid -- that it should be the last one. I'd find myself with renewed motivation and confidence, only to find another dead at my hands. 

We have three subjects left. They aren't aware of the fate of their predecessors. Faye has informed me her latest prototype is complete and on its way. I can only hope I make the right decision.We lost our first subject today. A-01, Bronwyn Meijer. The procedure went really well, but I believe the neuroamp overheated, burning the portions of the brain where it had contact. I sent the results to Faye. She believes she has a solution, but my God. I've never lost a patient before.

I sent everyone home. Sean wanted to stay, but I told him to go. I know he needed to process what happened, too, and I didn't want to hold him back. I tell myself it was the neuroamp. That it wasn't my fault. But if it feels like an excuse, it must be.

And what will happen now? These trials aren't even approved and I already have a death on my hands. I thought I was signing up for new advancements in neuroscience, but if I'm not careful, this could ruin what I have left of my career.Today marks the start of a new adventure in neuroscience. Although Infinity LTD is still waiting for official approval, we're moving forward with testing their latest technology: an Internal Neuroamp. I can't tell you how excited I am to be on a new project and have a chance to regain some admiration among my colleagues. 

I've invited Sean to come work with me on the project since he's familiar with how I operate. Plus, like myself, I knew he could really use the credits. These procedures should be quick and simple, so it's really a matter of Infinity LTD's tech playing nicely with brain tissue. Dr. Faye Sengsavahn is the creator of this new neuroamp and she's assured me smooth sailing. Let's just hope with our combined expertise we find success. This could be the boost my career needs.

Did you see the reviews? These excerpts below are unacceptable and need redaction. This is a disaster. I need you to get in contact with all publications and get this rectified. 

"This latest attempt at the ultimate tourist attraction in space, a Zero-G casino that hopes to keep the drinks flowing and the credits rolling, ultimately feels like antiquated entertainment from the dimming lights of our ancestral city of sin..."

"I float my way to the lower level, to spend these lavish moments yanking a lever in hopes of rewarding myself with some credits. With nowhere to plop down my once rotund back pockets, I hover aimlessly in front of a bright black hole, where credits get pulled in with no hope of escaping. I insert my last few creds to be leeched from my now depleted bank account from the overpriced drinks..."

"To my surprise, I hit a match 3 and maybe luck is on my side. The surprise quickly fades to disappointment, as my payout is something surprisingly tangible. It is an official casino marked coin. Unlike the convenience of the CredStik, I must carry a handful of these cumbersome coins, which feel grimy between my fingers. Perhaps the owners thought the feeling of old age tender would make me feel accomplished. Instead, the thought of trading precious creds for any type of physical currency would make anyone born within the last 300 years angry, enough to want to eject themselves out into the vacuum of space rather than spend another minute here..."Hi Clarence,

12, 19, 36, 5

Dr. Haukkson is investigating.08.07.2308

09.01.2309

Conclusion: 
Biochemical analysis of subsurface bacterial colonies reveals near total collapse caused by the gasses released by the mining processes. 

Killing Apex Predators devastates a local colony temporarily, but they can rebound. 

The chemicals released from the mines, however, are 95% responsible for the collapse of the ecosystem. 

My full report including data, methodology, and analysis will be sent directly to the main office.
-- Dr. Helgi Hauksson

08.01.2309

Summary: 
The Apex Predator species is an important component of the Gagarin ecosystem. The species is eusocial and has a strict caste structure with drones, defenders, and a primary reproductive Gyne, or "Queen." 

The Gyne of each region reproduces irregularly, and waste produced by the nesting process is used exclusively by the soil microbes to form massive colonies below the surface. 

Full report sent to main office.
-- Dr. Helgi Hauksson07.01.2309

Summary: 
Below the surface of Gagarin exists a vast microbial colony network that spans much of the planet. These colonies contain many species of microbes working together to convert dust and organic material into soil. Without these colonies, Gagarin's entire ecosystem would be devastated.

Full report sent to main office.
-- Dr. Helgi Hauksson06.01.2309

Summary: 
If a local "Queen" (Gyne) in the regional hive of Apex Predators dies, one of the drones is promoted to Queen by consuming the remains of the previous Queen. The process of promotion takes several months.

Full report sent to main office.
-- Dr. Helgi Hauksson

Our goals for this quarter:

1. Establish culture
2. Perform audit of all activities on the starstation
3. Tighten budget and accounting
4. Improve documentationAs Administrator, it's important to establish the right culture. These are lessons I learned when earning my Master's in Business Administration, as well as during the development of the S.P.E.C.T.E.R. Management System. 

As management, it's our job to SUPERVISE aggressively, PROVIDE the relevant feedback, ENGENDER the appropriate amount of fear, so they CORRECT their behavior and TRAIN their minds to EXPECT your presence, Lastly, REPEAT the process. Using S.P.E.C.T.E.R. management, our researchers will be looking over their shoulder at all times, and subsequently, correct their behavior on their own. 

-- Helena Chambers, MBA, Chief Administrator of Starstation RE-939As you may have heard, we are changing our evacuation protocols. Lieutenant Abreu will brief all of you with the details. As long as I am the head of this starstation, the safety of management and high ranking officials will remain a priority, and the changes are designed to ensure that outcome.

-- Helena Chambers, MBA, Chief Administrator of Starstation RE-939

I've received the notes regarding Helena Chambers and I'll do my best to address all your concerns at our next meeting. I do understand why it can be difficult to have someone without a scientific background making decisions on the research, but please remember that at the end of the day, we are all pulling on the same rope. 

-- Dr. Ricardo BoschHey guys! Not be a worry wart, but I am slightly concerned about the psychoactive properties of species VP-0184 and the potential for involuntary abuse. 

I'm no snitch, but I've noticed a couple of really bizarre proposals as of late, including this one about "xenodigestion?" Not to call anyone out, but who cares how long a person can survive inside some predator's stomach? This isn't the best use of MAST resources guys, I'm sure Ricardo would agree.

-- Dr. Fernando PenaThis might be a coincidence, but the day after we discovered the psychoactive properties of that particular flora, Dr. Baines described this incredibly bizarre dream about being devoured by a snake. But you know how private he is about his research. I didn't push the issue because it's none of my business and because honestly, Dr. Baines scares me.

-- Anonymous

I've managed to convince the higher ups to increase the emergency shuttle count. Hopefully we never use them, and it ends up being the extreme waste of resources they claim it to be. 

-- Lieutenant AbreuI looked over the new evacuation protocols, and why are some of the administrative officials given priority, even over the children? Guys, I understand the importance of safeguarding leadership, but yo, what are we really doing here? This is NOT in line with UC guidelines.

-- Ensign SamuelI get your concerns Ensign, believe me, I do. But in order to get the extra ship I had to appeal to brass' need for self-preservation. Yes, officials will be given a security escort to the new shuttle, while everyone else will need to bear arms and reach the warehouse port. I understand this isn't a popular decision, but its Administrator Chambers' call. All we can do is try to make the best of it and use the drills to prepare everyone on the station.

-- Lieutenant Abreu

Hey guys! I know everyone on the security team is working SUPER hard and it's much appreciated. But I got an itch that needs scratching, so I gotta ask - is it me, or has security gotten lighter on the station? I know we're still in UC space, but is anyone worried we might be a little exposed out here?

-- Dr. Fernando PenaHey Fernando, I noticed that too. I think Helena mentioned something about having us undergo firearm training, which some of my team rolled their eyes at. I don't mind it myself, although I will point out there's children on this station and I don't want them mistaking a Sidestar for a toy.

-- Dr. Nikola MedvedenkoI understand both of your concerns and I wish I had more information for you, but the recent security cuts were not a budget decision, and Administrator Chambers is not to blame. Two of my marines actually got engaged (Emma and Hiroki), and decided they were tired of station life. We'll be bringing in replacements soon, but MAST needs to vet the hires.

-- Lieutenant AbreuWhaaaat?!!?!?! Congratulations to the newly engaged!

-- Dr. Fernando Pena

Everyone keep in mind with Emma and Hiroki's sudden departure we're going to need everyone to work extended shifts. I apologize for this, but the safety of this starstation is one thing we can't compromise. This will only be for a week, MAST is currently vetting several new hires to replace them.

-- Lieutenant AbreuFine with me so long as we get paid.

-- Ensign PascalI disagree with Ensign Pascal, Lieutenant. This isn't about pay, it's about our ability to defend the station. We're stretched thin as dental floss here.

-- Ensign WannamakerI understand your concerns, and I'm working with the administrative team to improve our evacuation protocols. We'll also be having a number of drills to practice. The scientists may complain, but it's for their own good.

-- Lieutenant Abreu

The damage to the <Alias=DerelictShipName> is extensive, but there is one bright side. <Token.Title=MiscText04>. Problem is, even though we know where it stems from, we can't find the parts to fix it. 

While we managed to get some of the base systems online by jury rigging some ship parts, we're going to need a Reactive Gauge if we want to fix the radiator. We should have one stored somewhere on the ship, but if we can't find it, we'll need to craft one.

By my estimates, we only have <Token.Value=RandomInt00> hours before we freeze to death.
<Token.Title=MiscText01>

It doesn't look like we're going to make it. As <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, I feel partly responsible. I can only hope the rest of my crew forgives me.

My body is going numb and my fingers are turning blue. I can't even hold the tools I need to craft this gauge.

<Token.Title=MiscText02>
<Token.Title=MiscText04>. Sadly, it doesn't look good. We're going to run out of air if we don't do something about it soon. The team says we'll need to craft a new Adaptive Frame using whatever materials we can gather. The rest of us are scouring the ship for a spare. I feel like there should be one somewhere on the ship.

Regardless, based on our calculations, if we don't do it in the next <Token.Value=RandomInt00> hours, we won't have enough air to stand, let alone finish the repairs.

<Token.Title=MiscText01>

I hate to say it, but things are looking grim. We didn't get the ship fixed in time, and the oxygen is all but depleted. Some of the crew have decided to take matters into their own hands. I told them I wouldn't stop them. 

But I'm going to ride it out though until the end and hope for a miracle. I just want to see <Token.Title=MiscText03> again one last time.<Token.Title=MiscText05> Hair loss, bleeding from the gums, and bruises under the skin. 

We've got maybe <Token.Value=RandomInt02> hours to fix the <Alias=DerelictShipName>, but repairs have hit a standstill. We need to replace one of the Control Rods in the ship reactor systems to help absorb the excess radiation, but we don't have the materials to craft one. There might be a spare somewhere on the ship though, just gotta keep looking.I've heard stories that back on Earth, when a ship took water, it was the Captain's responsibility to go down with the ship. And as <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, I guess that duty falls on me. It's just unfortunate the rest of the crew will share that distinction with me.

Look, I don't want to say I've given up, but the situation on the ship is bleak. The <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s computer network is down, and most of the crew is too sick from the radiation to finish the repairs.

<Token.Title=MiscText02><Token.Title=MiscText04>. That's the good news. The bad news is, everyone's been struggling with various symptoms, from dehydration to dizziness to headaches, but we've got to press on.

After the next break, I'm going to have our crew spend the next <Token.Value=RandomInt01> hours just trying to work on the ventilation issues. According to the mainframe computer, we're going to need more Isotopic Coolant to help dampen this heat. 

But that requires ionic liquids, rare tetraflourides, things we don't have on in ready supply on this ship. If we can't craft one, maybe we have some leftover in one of the containers.Most of the crew is suffering from heat exhaustion. As <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> it's my responsibility to look after them until the end, but I think right now, we all just want to be left alone, so we can pass in the manner we choose to. 

I think I'm going to ride it out in the cockpit and drink this bottle of <Token.Name=MIscText00>.

It won't help with the dehydration, but it'll help with everything else.
<Token.Title=MiscText04>. Namely, the corrosive gas leak. But with the network systems offline, we don't have access to the <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s automated repair systems.

I'm not a medical doctor, but as <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, I've asked the team to watch for symptoms of corrosive gas poisoning, which I've listed here:

- Nausea 
- Vomiting
- Shortness of breath
- Confusion
- Blurred vision

As for the ship, we need a Semimetal Wafer to restore the panel insulation and prevent further corrosion. There should be a spare on the ship, but if not, we'll have to craft it.

The gas is starting to flood the cockpit. It's probably too late.

I don't know what to even say here. You would think on the verge of death, I'd have something profound for my epitaph, but the words escape me.

Wish I was back in <Token.Name=MiscText03>. Maybe in the next life, I'll see the sky from its port again.We've found the source of the toxic gas leak. Sadly, as far as fixing it goes, we don't have access to the <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s auto-repair functions, because the mainframe computer network is offline.

We're going to have to go about the repairs manually. Once we plug the leak, we'll need to reinforce the hull and replace the Power Circuit that regulates the shields so they're always online. We probably have a spare somewhere on the ship, but if not, we'll have to craft it.

It's a lot of work for a crew that's working in a toxic environment. <Token.Title=MiscText05> I've listed a few of them here.

- Nausea 
- Vomiting
- Headaches
- Fainting

I've instructed any crew members who are free of symptoms to work double shifts to ease the pressure off the others. But I feel like that may be putting too much pressure on the right leg to compensate for the left.

<Token.Title=MiscText01> The gas has found its way into every module. I don't know if there are any survivors. It may be cowardly for the damn <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> to hide in the cockpit, but the only thing I can do is wait here and hail any ship that jumps into the <Alias=targetSystem> system.

We're all trapped inside this coffin, drifting to nowhere. The more the gas pours in, the more I can feel it choke my lungs.

<Token.Title=MiscText02>

When it comes to the crates, the crew is on a need to know basis. 

Fact is, I've been working this side job for the last four missions. There's the regular work, and there's the shipping of this xenofauna. One job provides the perfect cover for the other.

That is, so long as the crew doesn't start asking the wrong questions. Otherwise there may need to be some shuffling when we get back to <Token.Title=MiscText03>. As <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, that's within my authority.We saw the ship as soon as we grav jumped from <Token.Name=MiscText03>. Some of the crew said we should leave well enough alone, but as <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> I made the decision to search the vessel for any survivors.

Now I'm worried we brought something on board. After all, it's also my duty to bring the crew back safe to <Token.Name=MiscText02>. 

Hopefully, I'm just being paranoid. 

There's been reports of damages across the <Alias=DerelictShipName>, and I don't have an explanation for how or why it's happening.

We had a full audit done by the engineering team before we left. <Token.Title=MiscText01> Whatever happened, it was after we left orbit. And judging by the claw marks, I don't think this is from a solar flare.The creatures have overrun the ship. I don't know how the crew died, but I know I'm all that's left, based on the ship's manifest. Watching the number tick down to zero, I felt completely helpless. 

Management told us the ship was equipped to deal with situations like this, but the sonic emitter is damaged and access to the mainframe computer is blocked.

If I want to survive this, I'm going to have to go out there and turn it on.



<Token.Title=MiscText04>.

Apparently the machines are having trouble with their sensor modules, including targeting parameters. This may be related to the damage the ship suffered recently, but we'll need to run a full diagnostic to confirm.

As <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, I've made a decision to pause operations and remain in the <Alias=targetSystem> system until the matter is resolved.

<Token.Title=MiscText01>

The <Alias=Robots[0]> have started attacking the crew. I've tried to re-adjust their targeting parameters but nothing the network is down.

I've holed myself up in the cockpit, but I'll need to get to the rear decks to fish out some repair parts. Once I get the maInframe computer online, I can run a shutdown, but the odds of me making it out alive are slim to none.

<Token.Title=MiscText02>

I went to lunch with Ularu yesterday, and it was strange. I could sense something was off, but she denied it. Refused to tell me, as usual. I wonder what's up with her. It wasn't like her usual moods where she's questioning herself and her abilities. I've been having a few moments of disorientation lately. It's as if I spaced out completely. Perhaps it's these mind-numbing quarterly reviews. I'll have to make an appointment with my doctor just in case. Maybe even bring this up to my therapist.I know Yuko's been telling Lane all sorts of confidential information. Lane is pretty clean according to his files, and if anyone can get a bead on someone, it's Yuko. I guess we all need a sounding board. I took a peek inside her own files and, no surprise, she has an eye on him at all times. I don't get her obsession with watching us.

My Dear Ularu,

I believe I have a package of great importance that belongs to you. Shall we arrange for a pickup? 

- SHey Ularu,

I was able to confirm that Tomo Higashi did NOT have adequate supporting data for his last report. It looks like he built his own theory off a handful of observations and what he claims as "experience." Good thing Imogene rejected it, right?

That's his third offense, so Imogene and I both agree to recommend him for termination. I know you like to do the honors.

YukoUlaru,

Here are the confirmation numbers you wanted for the following shipments:

- 294739: Arboron NovaSeries: 2 dozen Novablast, 4 dozen NovaLight
- 532516: Audio Slates: 2 crates
- 952452: NeuroTac Mark IV: 4 units

All deliveries are on time. I'll notify you once shipping receives them.

Camden Cho
Operations: Supply Chain Manager
Ryujin IndustriesDear Ularu,

I wanted to personally apologize for my brother's behavior over dinner the other night. I believe he still harbors ill-will toward Ms. Imada, and, as you know, his mind simply isn't what it used to be. I know he rejected your offer of a medical neuroamp to help with his clarity, but I will keep trying to change his mind.

Although our last dinner together was an exception, he truly does enjoy seeing you. Your admiration and respect for him instantly bring back the man I once knew. I hope you'll still see us in the future.

Best,
Oliver

Camden,

As you may have heard, we are acquiring Infinity LTD. Like Tranquilitea and DRONE, I want a satellite office set up for them in the storage area we're currently using. I trust you can handle the logistics. 

Masako Imada
CEO, Ryujin IndustriesCamden,

As you may have heard, we are acquiring Infinity LTD. Per Genevieve's advice, we'd like to set up a satellite office here, similar to Tranquilitea and DRONE. We can put them in the unused office area that's currently collecting dust. Genevieve will be in touch the with the details. I trust you can handle the logistics. 

Ularu Chen
CEO, Ryujin IndustriesHey Cam,

I know you like people to go through the proper channels, but I really need a new computer set up for Tomo's old station. Dalton's already secured his current one, and we're looking to hire someone new asap. I'm hoping you can expedite this for your fellow peer. 

YukoCamden,

It's been brought to my attention, yet again, that you're being too vocal with your opinions on Neon's Administrator. Please keep in mind that we have several people working here with ties to Bayu, and things said in the office often find their way back to him. You know the importance of our relationship and I expect you to respond professionally whenever business may be associated with him.

Ularu Chen
COO, Ryujin IndustriesCamden,

I need the confirmation numbers for a series of shipments.

- Order #45832: Arboron NovaSeries: 2 dozen Novablast, 4 dozen NovaLight
- Order #45904: Audio Slates: 2 crates
- Order #46001: NeuroTac Mark IV: 4 units

Ularu Chen
COO, Ryujin Industries

Dalton,

Tomo Higashi is no longer with the corporation. Please see to the usual search and purge of his office equipment. I don't expect you'll find anything, save proof of his own incompetence, but let me know if you do.

Ularu Chen
COO, Ryujin IndustriesHey Dalton,

One of my tech's ran into some interesting encryption. I was hoping you could take a look and maybe tweak an algorithm or two to help crack it. You know. Simple stuff. I'll owe you lunch.

YukoDalton,

I'd like for you to review the current security levels for our subsidiaries. I've heard rumors that Taiyo engineers may have access to aspects of our R&D database that I suspect Veena had a hand in. While I support her wish to share knowledge, we cannot allow competitors to see this as a backdoor.

Masako Imada
CEO, Ryujin Industries.

bookTitle: Ervin Madani vs. Hephaestus Mining Company
bookText:
WITNESS: 
Dr. Helgi Hauksson was a hired zoologist and ecologist who worked for the Gagarin Mining Company. 

NOTES: 
He quit his job citing ethics violations. Force him to speak about details under oath.ITEM #002: Ervin Madani's Hunting License

STATUS: Missing. 

NOTE: Check with Town Hall Records if Ervin doesn't have a copy already. Would need Ervin's application number. Likely sent to his home.STATUS: Missing. 

COMMENTS: 
Waiting on documentation from the defendant. PLAINTIFF: 
Ervin Madani knowingly and illegally killed a creature critical to the survival of the Gagarin ecosystem.

DEFENSE: 
The Defense maintains that Madani was hired by Gagarin Mining Company to exterminate an aggressive creature and concealed any information about environmental effects from Mr. Madani.
ITEM #001: Mining Company Contract

STATUS: Unconfirmed.

BACKGROUND: Company claims they hired Ervin Madani only to monitor the creature, not kill it.

COMMENTS: 
The item was not supplied to the Defense for investigation. Cannot be verified as a real document.

Initiating Airlock for Zero G...Initiating Airlock for Normal Gravity (One G)...All employees must follow these guidelines when using the conveyer system, and when Zero G is active. Failure to do so can result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. 

The conveyer system is only to be used during package processing and inspection done in Normal Gravity. Initiating the conveyer system in Zero G can result in damaged packages and floating debris. This can be extremely dangerous and damaging to equipment and workers in the event that Normal Gravity is unexpectedly reinstated. 

Zero G should only be used when package processing and inspection is completed, and after receiving express approval from a supervisor. Zero G is only to be used for package transportation and storage. DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES RETURN TO NORMAL GRAVITY WHEN WORKERS ARE STORING PACKAGES IN ZERO G.

Customer Name: STAR CHild

Issue: Daaaaaamn, this computer is AMAZING! So BRRRRIGHT!!! I wonder if I can TELL the future witH this thing??????????. Holy CRAP I am so ZZZZZZZoned right now. Gotta go get MOOOOORE!

I believe the Mission is pure. But time is harsh and cruel. The machines break down. Clearly, there is no other reason none of us have succeeded and been sent out into the Settled Systems.

I feel I am close to revelation. Something that will shake the earth. But I am not there yet.

We remember things in our core. All of us. Even the great skeptic Roosevelt I've caught on two occasions saying something that surprised himself.

"I got carried away," he said the first time. And "I must've overheard it" the second.

Is it so strange that truth speaks to us through our body? Of times past? People have believed this since our earliest times. Some of us still believe.

Violet left. She joined the Renegades. She must've been a traitor all along.

Genghis is sly. His feints have counter-feints. But you are not the only one who knows how to handle a blade, Mongol.

The Renegades belief is a sickness that must be cured.I dreamt of the Kush again last night. The scrub, the trees, the soil. There is something to the sky there that haunts me. And our ancestral home, the Earth, is gone. Loss and grief sometimes overwhelms me. My kingdom is gone. My people aren't a people any more.

One day I would build something new born of the past. A new Kush. Something to inspire wonder for the ages!

But first I must pass the Test. I know one day I will be worthy.

The long hard strategy works. Another has joined our flock.

No matter how many lies Genghis spreads, or doubt Roosevelt fosters... the truth of the Mission cannot be denied. Given time the Believers will triumph by numbers alone.

Roosevelt said he remembers a time when there were but three of us. Now we are Legion. No one can stand against us.

FDR may hide it but he is as quick to draw a blade as I. His greatest weakness is this mask of civility. Yet... Yet he has bested my previous lives at every turn.

As much as I despise it... it may be his greatest strength, too. He tells people what they want to hear, and they eagerly soak it in. Flattery. Two-faced lies.

In every battle we've had, we've had traitors. He gets to people.

I want to shake them. Make them see. These are lies!

Why do you trust the machines? The machines that kill us, the machines that hobble us?

But they are too far gone. And Amanirenas is the worst of them.

There is no convincing them. I will free them in spite of themselves. Even if I have to kill every last one of them to make it so.It amuses me how nervous I make Ms. Lovelace. But she intrigues me. The robots taught me little of the new science.  So I piece it together with talks with her.

Last night Ada told me of her theories about cloning. About this DNA. Now I wonder if I'm even a clone of Genghis? 

I know from my education that the real Genghis is a mysterious figure. No one knows where he was buried, where he was born, or almost anything.

So how did they capture his DNA? Or did they? One way or the other, I may share his name - but I am my own man.I found the clues I left for myself. Old Mongol trail signs, invisible to the others.

It is gratifying to know that I never fall in with the Believers. I always rebel. I have tried so many ways to escape, but I cannot find a way. There is no way.

The Facility must be destroyed. That is the only path forward. But how...?



Every week, I visit Wyatt and he shows me the marvels of modern drink. So many flavors, so many varieties! Why did the robots give us such ample provisions in this department?

Wyatt surprised me with what he called "Cactus Wine." We literally howled at the moon!

I will make a Renegade of you yet, Wyatt. You deserve to be free.

Some of the mates have been complaining about watered-down drinks, like it's my fault we're serving this piss.

Not my fault they haven't been putting in the work to keep us supplied the way we should be. Maybe they should spend less time hanging at the bar and more at the Mission Boards.Naeva's on edge lately. Part of it is vouching for Rake, but she's been burned before. What's bloody changed is the timing. We're spread thinner than marmite right now, and the whole crew knows it. 

Maybe this new rook will pan out, but if things keep going bad, it's gonna be like rats leaving a sinking ship.This whole business with Kryx's Legacy has got the Nova buzzing. Personally, I think it's a whole lot of shite, but if I'm wrong I'll be the first one to admit I was a bloody fool. Had plenty of experience with that losing Maddie already.

Anyway, more creds will mean better drinks, and a cheerier mood around the pub. But if it ain't real, it'll be up to me to drown the sorrows.The Nova's never been this lively. Hell, even my spirits seem to have climbed a rung or two. Just now some rook called me "Fergus" and I didn't even blow his brains out. Just patted him on the back and poured him another drink. 

In fact, I kind of liked the sound of it. Fergus. Maybe this is a sign from Maddie that I need to retire from this life, and take the name "Bog" with it.

Lots of possibilities either way. It's a new day.This crew is bloody cursed.

Not only did the new rook turn out to be a rat, they handed the Legacy over to SysDef on a silver platter. Even if we survive this fight, we don't have the creds to survive a war.

Maddie, I'll see you soon love.

Robots A17, A18, and B7 have been given new shielding. The results of the Ballistic Endurance Test are as follows:

Robot A17

- Catastrophic failure after 3 minutes and 9 seconds. 

Robot A18

-  Catastrophic failure after 2 minutes and 0 seconds.

Robot B7

- Catastrophic failure after 3 minutes and 7 seconds. 


These results are not a significant improvement from Ballistic Endurance Test 003. 
There have been growing concerns regarding Crimson Fleet presence in the area. I hope this message will allay your fears. 

Yes, it's true that some Crimson Fleet have been spotted in our system. This is not cause for concern, however. Although it may seem like they are approaching our location, this is impossible. 

You have all been assured that this facility and your work is top secret. This is still the case and will not change. Even if the Crimson Fleet land on the planet, our location is still entirely secret. I assure you that you will all remain perfectly safe. 

In the event of an emergency, you will all be notified as soon as possible of evacuation procedures. However, I do not anticipate ever having to take such measures. 

Please continue your research as normal. If you have any further concerns, please speak with me directly. 

Thank you,

Chief Scientist FeldmanAll scientists should be advised that the pirates we have been monitoring have landed planetside. While this is a worrisome development, work will resume as normal. 

We are monitoring the situation and will update everyone on an emergency protocol should it be deemed necessary. However, as of now, you are all expected to resume work.

Please refrain from spreading panic amongst your coworkers and yourselves, and keep conduct professional at all times. 

Thank you,

Chief Scientist Feldman

Under no circumstances should members of the construction team be supplementing their meals with rations from the cargo shipments. The rations we receive each week keep us alive through the following week.

In addition, the rations in those shipments are tailored to our crew's individual dietary needs. You all filled out a nutrition form when you accepted this assignment. Do you want to find out what happens when I digest a Butcher's Best Turkey? I don't think so.

The next crew member caught stealing from the cargo containers will be sent into the wilderness to find their own food on this rock.

Sgt. Langdon

Description: Captain logged that jumps were off by a few thousand kilometers. Discovered that one of the drive coils was misfiring two ticks off polarity axis.

Description: Rotten egg smell reported to be emitting from the interior ventilation system. Did a sniff trace and found that one of the interior sewage lines had fractured and was leaking into vent shaft R23-SE-790.

Issue: Everything!

Description: Grav Drive destroyed, propulsion offline, weapons offline, multiple hull breaches, etc. Too much to list. Captain wants me to log everything separately, but I'll be damned if I'm going to bother.

Solution: None. Attack wrecked this bird. We're finished.

Status: Open

Manual P-Wave analysis of the cave system indicates that there is a lot more to this place than we first suspected.  The area beyond this cave appears as a "dead zone" - almost like we're looking into deep space, a huge deposit of pure nothingness.  Nothing we are aware of has properties like this.

I have a friend at Stroud who is into the sort of thing.  I'm sending him my findings to see if he has any experience with results like ours.We've had to dismiss the remaining staff, temporarily at least.  They've received what severance we can afford to give, as well as a promise that we'll bring them back on once our company has a real product that we can bring to market, or we secure funding from other sources.  This isn't the first time they've heard this so they took it as well as you could hope.I think it's important to remember that Glunch isn't a thing or a process or whatever, it's a state of mind.  Sure Glunch might be short for "Glob Lunch" but really it's a way of looking at the world.  Glunch is the way that sad sacks and lazy idiots have eaten since time immemorial.  The key to a good Glunch is the binding agent - most of the time you can use eggs (from chickens or whatever those gooey orbs they eat on Akila are) to create the basis for a glob, then cook it up with whatever you have lying around.  Chunks of chunks, the remains of another meal, even gravel!  Serve it between two slices of whatever refined grain slabs you have laying around and eat with a fork and knife.

We Glunch or the world Glunches us.

We believe that properties of the cavern have led to fungal growth with medicinal properties.  While spores consumed in the cave appear to dramatically reduce inflammation, the task of making this a viable commercial product can't proceed until we find some way to stabilize their properties.
The creatures that live in the cave system MUST be kept alive.  Our current working theory is that they interact with the spores in some way to create an ecosystem scaffold that allows for the properties we've observed.  Whether or not we can recreate that ecosystem in an industrial setting remains to be seen.

Water composition, humidity, and temperature seem to be minimal factors when considering growth rate. So long as adequate measures are met, fluctuation has little impact. While day length and availability of light clearly influence reproductive season, the variance we see in specimen mass sampled from our different test sites appears to be determined primarily by the diet of local herbivores. This claim is supported by numerous observations, though results are still inconclusive we suspect that the impact of their droppings on soil PH, moisture and overall molecular identity is statistically significant. Follow up on recent discovery of using composted fecal matter obtained from local herbivorous specimen and their impact on Time to Maturity (TTM)  of selected plant-like reproductive cycle. Determine if specific compounds are responsible for accelerated growth or if it is necessary that the fertilizer have the entire nutrient profile.A unique compound derived from Sulfanilamide appears to be the key to approximating an ideal biome for this particular specimen to thrive in. When crossing a specific saturation threshold we see Polymerase Chain Reactions (PCR) occurring at 3 times the standard rate. The impact on substrate-level phosphorylation, and consequently, cellular respiration is remarkable. We suspect that means the corresponding creatures' access to food sources may fluctuate based on local availability. This would explain the potential for such great variety in the size we see of these mature plants in different geographical locations.

Technically speaking there is nothing wrong with this particular model. Working as intended I reckon. Unlike the last version it can and will hoist a missile into position. Never mind the sparks, all part of the process. And I do appreciate how the suspension coil doesn't completely throw off the alignment. Yeah burning up 5 aggregate circulating devices was definitely painful, so I'm glad we've gotten over that hill. But see that's where the compliments end. 

The bearing surface for the torsion spring in component 6C seems to be composed of a robust plastic material. It really holds everything in place quite well. Until it gets mildly warm. See now that's a problem when you put this thing together like this such that its adjacent to both Air Preheaters and the Fluid Agitator (that thing gives off so much fucking heat, what the hell are y'all thinking). 

Look you guys have provided us with some remarkable tech but poor physical integrity of these components results in compromised behavior leading to noticeable and frequent inconsistencies of proper cycling of states. So in other words, the damn thing barely works. Please, we've gone back and forth testing this 6 times now. Test your product, or we will find a new supplier!Use parts that will not melt next to hot things. Ideally, loading a missile into the ship's launching system does not create a source of anxiety for the customer (in which they lose days of sleep worrying about their eventual fiery death).Assembly notes are actually pretty good. Everything was really concise and clear. The diagrams are beautiful. Nothing caught on fire, so I'm honestly relieved.I've always had a burning passion for product design, so this experience has really reignited that flame. But honestly, I'm running out of snarky remarks to litter through my sternly worded messages. I guess this is the last one.

The Conduction Grid is an electromagnetic absorption system utilizing the shroud suspended above Neon as a lightning conduction array.

When a lightning discharge is created between the array and the troposphere, the energy is dispersed evenly across the system's receptors. It is then transported via conductive conduits into our processing facility, where it passes through a series of polyphasic capacitors and rectifiers. This ensures that the incoming energy is equalized from its original positive and negative state. Once the energy is cleaned, it gets stored in power storage cells located in the Power Core of the facility.==Generdyne Power Core Status==

Storage Cell 01 - Green (Maximum Capacity)
Storage Cell 02 - Green (Maximum Capacity)
Storage Cell 03 - Green (Maximum Capacity)
Storage Cell 04 - Green (Maximum Capacity)
Storage Cell 05 - Yellow (Active)
Storage Cell 06 - Orange (Active)Offloading... 

Plans Downloaded

Mr. Brennan,

I'm looking forward to meeting you to discuss our potential partnership. I know opportunities to buy Martian ore don't come up very often, so I want you to know I'm willing to make a very generous offer. But, let's discuss in person, shall we? My schedule is flexible, so tell me what works for you.

Kind Regards,
Javier LindholmPeter, your psychological evaluation turned up some interesting stuff. I think it would be good for you to come speak with me sometime so I can make sure you understood the questions properly and you can provide some clarity on your answers. For instance, I think you may have completely misunderstood question number 6. I'm not even sure that person works on Mars, let alone for this company. Let's chat a bit and try to resolve this so I can submit a proper evaluation. 

Thanks!
-Gilly
Mr. Brennan,

I'm writing to you to let you know that you have an outstanding tax balance. As a consequence, we've held up a shipment for you in hopes that it will motivate you to speak with us and come pay off your balance so that we can release it to you. As we value Deimos as a local business, we don't wish to see this escalated any further than it needs to due to a personal matter such as this. Thank you for understanding.

-Glen Hurst
Governor, CydoniaHello, loser! Since I learned that you don't even check your work computer for actual work purposes, I realized I can say anything I want here and you'll never know! Blarg! Boogedy boogedy boo! See, I can just say nonsense if I want and it doesn't matter! But here's some real truth for you: You've got a BO problem! You're lazy and incompetent! You're an entitled trust fund kid who lucked into your position because of who you know, but not even that - it's because of who your daddy knows, yet they can't fire you because it'd be bad for the company for some reason. What a joke! You never even learned my name. I was your assistant for three damn years! It's Tim! It's not even hard to say! It's three letters! Working for you made me so mad! I'm glad I quit! I bet you didn't even notice!

Tim O'Shea
